Policy: Leasehold Valuation Tribunals (Procedure) (Wales) Regulations 2004 (S.I. No. 681 (W.69) of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations regulate the procedure to be followed in connection with applications made to a leasehold valuation tribunal. Regulation 3 provides for general particulars to be included with all applications and specified particulars to be included with specified applications as set out in the Schedules. Regulation 4 provides for notice to be given by the applicant and respondent where an application is made under Part 4 of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1987, while regulation 5 provides for notice to be given by the tribunal in the case of other applications. Regulation 5 also gives the tribunal the discretion to give notice by local advertisement. Regulation 6 provides for the procedure to be followed where a person requests to be joined as a party to the proceedings. Regulation 7 provides that an application may be treated as withdrawn if a fee is not paid for a period of one month from the date on which it becomes due. Regulations 8-10 provide for securing consistency where numerous applications are or may be brought in respect of the same or substantially the same matters. Regulation 12 provides for pre-trial reviews and allows the tribunal to give any directions that may be necessary for the expeditious and economical disposal of proceedings. Regulation 14 provides for hearings, it allows the tribunal to determine the procedure and gives the tribunal the discretion to give less than 21 days notice of the hearing where there are exceptional circumstances. Regulation 15 provides for a hearing to be postponed or adjourned.
Subject: Land & soil

Policy: Leasehold Reform (Collective Enfranchisement and Lease Renewal) (Amendment) (Wales) Regulations 2004 (S.I. No. 670 (W.63) of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations amend the principal Regulations 1993 which set out the procedure to be followed in relation to applications for collective enfranchisement and lease renewal made under the Leasehold Reform, Housing and Urban Development Act 1993. The amendments are consequential to amendments made to sections 13 and 39 of the 1993 Act by section 120 and Schedule 14 of the Commonhold and Leasehold Reform Act 2002 (c. 15) abolishing the residence test: one of the qualifying rules for tenants making claims for collective enfranchisement and lease renewal which required the tenant to have occupied the flat as his only or principal home for the last twelve months or for periods amounting to three years in the last ten years. In respect of lease renewal, the test has been replaced with a requirement that the tenant has to have been a long leaseholder of the flat for two years.

Policy: Agricultural Marketing Authority Act 2004 (No. 2 of 2004).
Policy_Content: The Agricultural Marketing Authority is established under section 3 as a body corporate. The functions of the Authority are: (a) to assist the producers of agro-produce on marketing of their products; (b) to identify markets for and to facilitate and develop marketing of agro-produce; (c) to purchase, sell and export and import agro-produce or import agro-input; etc. (sect. 4). The Board may by Order in the Gazette and in consultation with the Minister, declare an area or premises to be a collection centre for purposes of this Act (sect. 8). The manager of a collection centre may:(a) inspect any agro-produce that is brought to the collection centre; (b) refuse to purchase or sell or refuse to accept for export, any agro-produce if the produce is unfit for human consumption, damaged or unmarketable; (c) dispose for other use any agro-produce that is not purchased or sold or unfit for human consumption; (d) collect information from a buyer, seller or supplier in relation to an agro-produce or agro-input; and (e) take or obtain a sample of any agro-produce for testing, educational or experimental purposes. The Minister may, after consulting the Board, give specific or general policy directions to the Board.

Policy: Order No. 67 of the State Committee on Land Resources validating the Regulation on the modalities of legalization, issuing and registration of the injunctions in case of the exposure of the infringement of land legislation.
Policy_Content: The Regulation establishes the modalities of legalization, issuing and registration of the injunctions issued by the state inspectors for land tenure and protection of land for the purpose of stopping the exposed infringement of land legislation and elimination of the consequences thereof. The provisions of the Regulation shall be compulsory for the state inspectors of the State Inspection for Control over Land Tenure and Protection of Land and its territorial branches authorized to carry out the state control over land tenure and protection of land in conformity with the requirements of land legislation. Injunction is the compulsory written request of the state inspector issued to the legal and natural persons for the purpose of stopping the exposed infringement of land legislation and elimination of the consequences thereof. The state inspector that has issued injunction must record it in the register within three days from the date of issue. Appeal against the decision of the authorized official can be filed within ten days from the date of issue.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 111 on licensing activities related to sources of ionizing radiation.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes the modalities for licensing activities related to sources of ionizing radiation. The following activities related to sources of ionizing radiation shall be subject to compulsory licensing: (a) research and development; and (b) mining, extraction, processing, storage, transportation, recycling and disposal. Licensing terms and conditions include: (a) observance by the applicant of the legislation on radiation safety; (b) availability of equipped facilities; (c) availability of radiation safety services; and (d) means of ensuring radiation safety in case of nuclear disaster or accident. Applicants must submit the following documentation: (a) application; (b) notarized copy of the state registration certificate; (c) expert opinion of the state inspectorate on the applicant’s compliance with the licensing terms and conditions; and (d) copy of the receipt for payment of the licensing fee.

The main tasks of the Ministry shall be: (1) fire safety supervision; (2) organization and carrying out the arrangements in the zone of alienation of Chernobyl and protection of the human beings and territory against radioactive contamination; (3) carrying out the arrangements for the reduction of radiation level in the contaminated zone; (4) carrying out the arrangements for the prevention of natural disasters and technological accidents the liquidation of the consequences thereof; (5) early warning of the population of the imminent disasters and operation of the early warning and emergency intervention systems; (6) decontamination of the areas contaminated as a result of the Chernobyl Catastrophe.

Tout traitement aérien est soumis à une déclaration préalable comportant les éléments suivants: - le formulaire prévu à cet effet, dûment rempli; - à défaut d'avoir indiqué sur ce formulaire la localisation précise des points de ravitaillement de l'aéronef, un plan au 25 000 précisant la localisation de ces points; - toute autre information jugée utile par le donneur d'ordre ou l'opérateur. Policy: Regional Law No. 8-ZKO “On turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates turnover of agricultural land with a view of conservation of precious productive agricultural land. It establishes minimum agricultural land areas resulting from land consolidation for open land - 1 ha, for areas under glass - 0,05 ha. Minimum agricultural land area for drained and irrigated agricultural land shall not be less than 100 ha. Maximum agricultural land area that can be owned by a single natural or legal person within the boundaries of a single municipal unit shall not exceed 10 percent of total available agricultural land area.

Policy: Regional Law No. 172-ZKO “On turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates relations dealing with ownership, management, tenure and disposal of agricultural land and shares in common property of agricultural land. It shall not be applicable to agricultural land allotted for subsistence farming, gardening, horticulture and stockbreeding. Minimum land area of consolidated agricultural land plots pertaining to public, municipal and common land ownership shall be 0,5 ha. Maximum agricultural land area within the boundaries of a single municipal unit that can be owned by one natural or legal person shall not exceed 20 percent of total available agricultural land. Regional Administration shall have preferential rights for purchase of agricultural land at selling cost. Agricultural land plot can be expropriated if the owner have not used it for agricultural purposes for the period of three years.

Policy: Green Industries SA Act 2004.
Policy_Content: This Act establishes the green industry. The primary objectives of Green Industries SA are: a)	promote waste management practices that, as far as possible, eliminate waste or its consignment to landfill; and b) promote innovation and business activity in the waste management, resource recovery and green industry sectors, recognising that these areas present a valuable opportunity to contribute to the State's economic growth. Green industry is a reference to: a) any business for the production of goods that demonstrates the application of the guiding principles set out in section 3A in the manner of production and the goods or services themselves; or b) any business activity carried on in support of, or in connection with, an activity referred to in paragraph (a), including research and development, education and marketing. These are its guiding principles: principles of circular economy; waste management hierarchy; principles of ecologically sustainable development; best practice methods and standards should be pursued in: (i) waste management; and (ii) the efficient use of resources.

Policy: National Programme to Abate the Climate Change Impacts in the Czech Republic
Policy_Content: The Program To Abate the Climate Change Impacts lays down the climate protection strategy of the Czech Republic and has been developed in accordance with the requirements of Council Decision 99/296/EC. The Program provides national targets and appropriate policies and measures to ensure meeting of the reduction emission targets to the maximum possible degree in the sense of international agreements to reflect existing and future social and economic conditions and to promote sustainable development. A number of policies and measures are being implemented in the Czech Republic to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These consist in both framework measures and measures concentrating on a certain aspect or sector. Adaptation measures consist of a set of potential adaptations of a natural or anthropogenic system to an actual or expected climate change and its impact. The Program is composed of the following Sections: Introduction (Sec. 1); Climate change and its global impacts (Sec. 2); Climat change as an international issue (Sec. 3); Climate change and its impacts in the Czech Republic (Sec. 4); Greenhouse gas emissions in CR in 1990 to 2001 (Sec. 5); Greenhouse gas emissions in CR to 2030 (Sec. 6); Policies and measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions (Sec. 7); Adaptation measures (Sec. 8); Costs of greenhouse gas emissions reduction (Sec. 9); Targets and priorities in the Czech Republic in the area of climate change (Sec. 10).
Subject: Air & atmosphere
Geographical_area: Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries

Policy: Decree No. 6 on  subdivision of  plots of land.
Policy_Content: The present Decree  establishes the rules governing land consolidations owned by citizens and legal persons irrespective of the nature of tenure and the presence or  absence of constructions thereon. The plots of land registered  in the state land cadastre can be subject to consolidation or splitting up. The adjoining plots of land  not exceeding the established maximum size ceiling, owned by citizens, can be consolidated. Splitting up of the plot of land can be carried out  provided that there shall be no infringement of fire prevention, sanitary, ecological, construction and other requirements. Annex 1 contains the application form for the consolidation and splitting up of plots of land and Annex 2 the form of related survey practice.

Policy: Règlement grand-ducal portant modification du règlement grand-ducal modifié du 11 février 2002 fixant les modalités d’application de l’indemnité compensatoire annuelle à allouer aux agriculteurs dans les zones défavorisées.
Policy_Content: Le présent règlement modifie certains articles du règlement grand-ducal susmentionné. Par exemple, l'article 6 est remplacé par les dispositions suivantes: « Art. 6. (1) Il ne peut être alloué qu’une seule indemnité compensatoire par exploitation agricole, même si elle est gérée par plusieurs exploitants. (2) En cas d’association de deux ou plusieurs exploitations, les exploitations associées sont considérées comme constituant une seule unité technico-économique et elles sont à réunir dans une seule demande de paiements à la surface. (3) Les plafonds prévus à l’article 7, sous a) relatifs aux hectares éligibles sont multipliés par un coefficient déterminé en fonction des unités de travail annuel des exploitations conformément au tableau de correspondance de l’annexe III. Les unités de travail annuel précitées (UTA) sont obtenues en tenant compte des données relatives aux différentes productions déclarées dans la demande de paiements à la surface des exploitations et des valeurs moyennes reprises au tableau de l’annexe II. (4) Les montants et plafonds visés à l’article 7, sous b), sont applicables aux exploitants bénéficiaires d’une pension de vieillesse, à moins qu’une personne affiliée à la Caisse de maladie agricole comme membre ressortissant ne travaille à titre principal sur l’exploitation concernée». En outre deux annexes sont ajoutées. Le texte comprend 7 articles.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Keyword: Financial agricultural measures,Subsidy/incentive,Less favoured areas,Farming,Agricultural development

Policy: Merchant Shipping (Prevention of Pollution by Garbage) Regulations.
Policy_Content: With a view to preventing marine pollution from ships, these regulations govern disposal of garbage. The provisions apply both to Maltese ships, wherever they may be, and to other ships while they are in Malta. The disposal of all plastics from a ship into the sea outside special areas is prohibited (reg. 4). The disposal from a ship outside special areas of garbage other than plastic is prohibited, except where it is made as far as practicable from the nearest land and the conditions specified under regulation 4(2) are fulfilled. When garbage is mixed with other discharges the more stringent requirements shall apply. Regulation 5 concerns the disposal of garbage within special areas; regulation 6 concerns the disposal of garbage into the sea within five hundred metres of fixed or floating platforms.
Subject: Sea, Environment gen.

Policy: Regional Law No. 3-ZKO “On environmental protection”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law establishes plenary powers of the Regional administration in the sphere of environmental protection and ensures human rights to favourable environment and access to reliable information on the state of environment. State control in the sphere of environmental protection shall be performed by state ecological inspectors that can enforce environmental legislation and apply penalties for environmental offences. Public environmental inspection shall be performed by associations of citizens. Regional territory shall be subject to state environmental monitoring. Sources of negative environmental impact shall be subject to mandatory state registration. Negative environmental impact shall require payment of environmental fees.

Policy: Order No. 68-P of the Minister of Environmental Protection on Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA).
Policy_Content: The Order establishes the basic provisions for carrying out Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) of the projected economic and other activities at all stages of their implementation according to pre-project and project documentation. EIA shall be applicable to: (a) pre-investment substantiation; (b) land use planning; (c) technical and economic substantiation; (d) certification of techniques, technology and materials; (e) licences for nature- and waste management; (f) requirements for environmental protection and ecological safety of the population. EIA is based upon the principles of: (a) all-inclusiveness; (b) alternative; (c) adequacy; (d) conservation; (e) compatibility; (f) flexibility; (g) compulsory public participation. EIA consists of three stages the outcome of which is legalized as the decision of the state environmental audit. The three stages are: (a) review of the state of environment; (b) preliminary EIA; (c) final EIA.
Subject: Environment gen.

The Federation of Petroleum and Derivates Supplying Companies shall collect data from its member companies and forward it to the Energy Centre. The Energy Centre shall elaborate the data received and shall keep a data bank that can be accessed and controlled easily by the EC Commission. The list of petroleum derivates are listed in Annex 1.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 112 on land tenure of radioactively and chemically contaminated land, carrying out drainage and land reclamation thereon, setting up protection zones and conservation of objects situated thereon.
Policy_Content: Contaminated land depending upon the type and the level of contamination or indices of negative impact upon human health and environment caused by contamination, shall be transferred into reserve land for the purpose of conservation, shall be used in conformity with purposeful use thereof under special conditions of land tenure and shall be used in conformity with purposeful use thereof without the establishment of special conditions of land tenure if contamination level and indices of negative impact do not exceed the established rates. Special conditions of land tenure of contaminated land and use restrictions thereof shall be established by the federal executive bodies, regional executive bodies and local self-government with the consideration of the outcome of special research depending upon the type, the level of contamination and indices of negative impact upon human health and environment caused by contamination.

Policy: Loi organique n° 2004-192 du 27 février 2004 portant statut d'autonomie de la Polynésie française.
Policy_Content: Ce texte permet à la Polynésie française de bénéficier des dispositions de l’article 74 de la Constitution qui prévoit, depuis la révision constitutionnelle relative à l’organisation décentralisée de la République de mars 2003, que certaines collectivités d’outre-mer «peuvent accéder à l’autonomie dans la République».  Le texte prévoit une série de transferts de compétence au profit de l’archipel et une reconnaissance accrue aux langues polynésiennes. Des garanties démocratiques nouvelles seraient introduites dans le statut: compétences propres accordées aux communes, droits supplémentaires pour les élus minoritaires, instauration du droit de pétition et du référendum décisionnel local. L’ancrage de la Polynésie française dans la République serait cependant garanti par le maintien à l’Etat de la totalité de ses compétences régaliennes: défense, politique étrangère, monnaie, justice, sécurité, ordre public, garantie des libertés publiques.

Policy: Order No. 51 of the Ministry of Agrarian Policy validating the Regulation on soil monitoring of agricultural land.
Policy_Content: The system of soil monitoring of agricultural land is a component of the state system of environmental monitoring and represents the system of observation, collection, processing, transfer, storage and analysis of information regarding variation of indices of the qualitative composition of soil, its fertility, elaboration of scientifically substantiated recommendations as regards decision-making for the prevention of negative processes and liquidation of the consequences thereof. The objects of soil monitoring shall be agricultural land (arable land, perennial plants, meadows, pastures, land under temporary conservation). Soil monitoring of agricultural land shall be carried out in conformity with the national and regional programs of soil monitoring. Soil monitoring of agricultural land shall be carried out for the purpose of timely exposure of the composition of soil, assessment thereof, elimination of the consequences of the negative processes and elaboration of scientifically substantiated systems of farming and agricultural technologies.
Subject: Land & soil

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 9238/332 relating to limit and guide values for benzene and carbon monoxide in ambient air.
Policy_Content: The Decree aims at implementing the provisions of article 7 of Law No. 1650/86 “on the protection for the environment. It also aims at harmonizing the Greek legislative frame with the provisions of Directive 2000/69/EC relating to limit values for benzene and carbon monoxide in ambient air so as to ensure that all appropriate measures are taken in order to avoid, prevent or reduce harmful effects on human health and the environment which might arise from concentrations of benzene and carbon monoxide in ambient air. The Decree is composed as follows: objective (art. 1); definitions (ambient air, upper and lower assessment thresholds, etc. (art. 2); benzene (art. 3); carbon monoxide (art. 4); protective measures required in the event of limit values being exceeded (art. 5); requirements in the event of non-exceedance of limit values (art. 6); assessment of concentrations (art. 7); transmission of information and reports to the Commission (art. 8); public information (art. 9); sanctions (art. 10). The thirteen Annexes included in the text constitute integral part of this Decree.
Subject: Air & atmosphere
Geographical_area: Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, Mediterranean, Southern Europe

Policy: Less Favoured Area Support Scheme (Scotland) Regulations 2004 (S.S.I. No. 70 of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations apply to holdings in respect of which the Scottish Ministers are the competent authority under the Integrated Administration and Control System Regulations 1993. Applications for less favoured area support ("LFAS") are to be made to the Scottish Ministers on a date which they shall determine each year. Failure to meet the deadline will result in reduction of the payment of support (reg. 3). Eligibility for payment of LFAS is dependent upon the applicant meeting the criteria set out in regulation 4. It can only be paid to an applicant who carries out an eligible agricultural activity (defined in reg. 2(1)) on eligible land (defined in reg. 6). No payment will be made where the amount of eligible land is less than 3 hectares (reg. 5). There is provision at regulation 7 to determine to whom payment should be made where a holding is transferred during a Scheme Year. LFAS is paid for eligible hectares on farms in Scottish less favoured areas at specified rates (regs. 8 and 12). The rate is fixed according to the grazing category (reg. 9 and Schedule 4) and the fragility of the parish in which the main farm of the applicant lies (reg. 12 and Schedule 7).
Subject: Agricultural & rural development

Policy: Law No. 3233 ratifying the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety to the Convention on Biological Diversity.
Policy_Content: This law ratifies the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety, an international agreement on biosafety, as a supplement to the Convention on Biological Diversity. The Protocol was signed on 29 January 2000. The Biosafety Protocol seeks to protect biological diversity from the potential risks posed by living modified organisms resulting from modern biotechnology. In accordance with the precautionary approach, the objective of the Protocol is to contribute to ensuring an adequate level of protection in the field of the safe transfer, handling and use of 'living modified organisms resulting from modern biotechnology' that may have adverse effects on the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity, taking also into account risks to human health, and specifically focusing on transboundary movements. The law, consisting of two articles (ratification and entry into force), adopts all the provisions of the Protocol and the Annexes attached therewith.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 188 validating the Regulation on forest registration and monitoring.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes that the State forest register shall be integral part of the state registration system and it shall be kept by the authorized forest institution. The State forest register contains data on the legal status of forest estate, distribution thereof among forest owners, qualitative and quantitative state of forests and distribution thereof by categories. Owners of private forest shall submit data thereon required for recording in the State forest register. The State forest register shall be interrelated with the state land cadastre. Data on the plots of forest land shall be taken over from the state land cadastre. Forest monitoring shall be structured on three levels: (a) national; (b) regional; and (c) local. Forest monitoring shall include: (a) systematic observations; (b) assessment of forest resources; and (c) forecast of the state of forests for a given period of time.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 161 regarding validation of the Regulation on the modalities of monitoring of ozone layer as part on national system of environmental monitoring.
Policy_Content: The present Regulation determines the modalities of carrying out monitoring of ozone layer and use of data thereof. Monitoring of ozone layer is integral part of environmental monitoring. Objects of monitoring is layer of atmospheric ozone situated in the stratosphere. Monitoring of ozone layer is the system of observation of the state of ozone layer, its valuation and prognostication of changes for the purpose of timely exposure of negative environmental and anthropogenesis factors. Information obtained as a result of monitoring of ozone layer comprises: 1) data on general state of ozone in the atmosphere and its vertical distribution; 2) data on spectral distribution and levels of terrestrial ultra-violet rays; 3) data on contents of terrestrial ozone; 4) data on other atmospheric parameters necessary for qualitative monitoring of ozone layer; 5) valuation and prognostication of change of state of ozone layer and terrestrial ultra-violet rays over the territory of the Republic of Belarus; 6) valuation and prognostication of negative impact of depletion of ozone layer on human health and ecosystems. The Ministry of Education is entitled with the task of collection, storage, processing, analysis and concession of information obtained as a result of monitoring of ozone layer.
Subject: Air & atmosphere

The present Law is applicable to all Federal Acts dealing with environment and water protection. The text consists of 89 articles divided into 4 Parts as follows: General provisions and principles (1); Environment protection (2); Water protection (3); Final and transitional provisions (4).

Policy: Regulation on Formation of the Primitive and Supreme Court to Investigate the Violations of Practitioners in the Field of Agriculture and National Resources Engineering.
Policy_Content: This Regulation, which consists of 19 articles, aims to establish primary and supreme courts for investigation in violations committed in the field of agricultural and national resources engineering. According to the Regulation, primary courts consist of 5 members appointed for period of 4 years. These courts deal with offences related to the guild and professional misconduct. The decision of these courts may be appealed in period of 30 days to the supreme courts. The supreme courts consist of 7 members appointed for a period of 4 years. The  decisions made are based on a majority vote.

Policy_Content: These Rules consist of 21 rules divided into 6 Parts: Preliminary (I); Rules for navigation (II); Arrival and Departure (III); Safety and emergency regulations (IV); Safety in port (V); General (VI). Rule 3 deals with collision regulations. Arrival and departures of vessels shall be notified to the Port Officer. Every vessel lying within the Port shall have contingency plans and procedures to attend to emergencies involving oil spill, explosion, fire grounding, abandonment and other maritime casualties. Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage and above, and any other vessel of 400 gross tonnage and above, when calling at the Port shall carry on board a shipboard pollution emergency plan. Policy: Provisions on the conservation of biological resources in Bohai Sea.
Policy_Content: The purpose of these Provisions is to protect, increase and rationally utilize the biological resources in Bohai Sea, protect the ecological environment of the Bohai Sea area, safeguard the lawful rights and interests of fishery workers, and promote the sustainable development of the fishery industry in Bohai Sea. The Provisions consist of 42 articles divided into 6 Chapters: General provisions (I); Aquaculture and fishing (II); Reproducing of biological resources (III); Protection of biological resources (IV); Environmental protection of fishery water areas (V); Supplementary provisions (VI). Whoever wants to engage in aquaculture production or fishing shall file an application to the coastal fishery administrative department (arts. 9 to 16). It is prohibited to breed in Bohai Sea any of the crossbred varieties, genetically modified varieties and other varieties not originally existing in Bohai Sea. The State encourages entities and individuals to invest to reproduce biological resources in Bohai Sea in various forms such as artificial release for the purpose of reproducing, building artificial reefs, etc. Chapter IV prescribes provisions on fishing, fishing gear, fishing areas, fishing periods, etc. The coastal fishery administrative department shall legally take part in the environmental impact assessment and in the projects of coastal engineering, marine engineering, or projects of waste dumping or of marine sewage discharging outlets, etc., study the impacts upon the biological resources and the environment of fishery water areas, and propose specific requirements and measures on the protection of biological resources and the environment of fishery water areas.
Subject: Environment gen., Fisheries, Sea

Policy: Decision No. 280/2004/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning a mechanism for monitoring Community greenhouse gas emissions and for implementing the Kyoto Protocol.
Policy_Content: The present Decision establishes a mechanism for: (a) monitoring all anthropogenic emissions by sources and removals by sinks of greenhouse gases not controlled by the Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer in the Member States; (b) evaluating progress towards meeting commitments in respect of these emissions; (c) implementing the UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol. Having due regard to the overall objective of the Kyoto Protocol (namely stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level which prevents dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system), Member States and the Community as a whole shall fulfill their international obligations particularly by adopting national and Community special programmes (art. 2). Member States shall report to the Commission the information prescribed by article 3 as to their emissions. The Commission is required to compile each year a Community greenhouse gas inventory as well as a Community greenhouse gas inventory report (art. 4).
Subject: Air & atmosphere
Keyword: Pollution control,Air quality/air pollution,Emissions,Ozone layer,Environmental planning,Data collection/reporting,Clean development mechanism

Policy: Vessel Traffic Monitoring and Reporting Requirements Regulations, 2004 (L.N. 458 of 2004).
Policy_Content: Pursuant to Directive 2002/59/EC, these Regulations apply to vessel traffic monitoring and information system with a view to (i) enhancing the safety and efficiency of maritime traffic, (ii) improving the response of authorities to incidents, accidents or potentially dangerous situations at sea, including search and rescue operations, and (iii) contributing to a better prevention and detection of pollution by ships. These provisions apply to ships of 300 gross tonnage and upwards. Warships, fishing vessels and the ships specified in regulation 3 are excluded from the scope. The Malta Maritime Authority is responsible for the implementation of these Regulations. Regulation 6 concerns the duty of operators, agents or masters of ships to notify the Authority prior to entry into port or territorial waters. Additional notification obligations concern ships carrying dangerous or polluting goods. Regulation 11 deals with reporting of incidents and accidents at sea. Regulation 14 provides for the establishment of the Maritime Safety and Pollution Prevention Committee. Regulation 15 sets out the penalties to be applied in case of infringement.

Policy: Assessment and Management of Environment Noise Regulations (L.N. 193 of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations aim at defining a common approach in order to avoid, prevent or reduce on a prioritized basis the harmful effects, including annoyance, due to the exposure to environmental noise. Regulation 2(1) specifies the actions to be implemented progressively, including: (a) the determination of exposure to environmental noise through noise mapping; (b) making information on environmental noise and its effects available to the public. These Regulation aim also at providing a basis for the development of measures intended to reduce noise emitted by the major sources, particularly road and rail vehicles and infrastructure, aircraft, outdoor and industrial equipment and mobile machinery. The noise indicators referred to in Annex I to Directive 2002/49/EC. The assessment methods to be implemented shall be those specified in Annex II to the same Directive. Policy: Presidential Resolution on establishing State Agricultural Joint Stock Company of Turkmenistan.
Policy_Content: The President enacts to establish the State Agricultural Joint Stock Company of Turkmenistan setting high production of grain, cotton other agricultural crops by effective use of arable lands, irrigation water and agricultural machinery as its main task. The State Agricultural Joint Stock Company of Turkmenistan is to establish lower joint stock companies in velayats and etraps and executive departments in the gengeshliks in accordance with established order. The State Agricultural Joint Stock Company of Turkmenistan is to: 1) at its own expense employ wage labourers to produce wheat, cotton and other agricultural crops on vested lands; 2) process 60 per cent of cotton produced and put products at free prices on national and foreign markets, and allocate earned profit for development of sectors included into the Joint Stock Company; 3) extend input tax and insurance benefits for manufacturers over the State Agricultural Joint Stock Company as well as to be exempted from obligatory transfer of profits in foreign currency to the Interbank Foreign-Currency Exchange of Turkmenistan and Foreign-Currency Insurance Fund of Turkmenistan.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Cultivated plants

Policy: Acquisition of Farm Equipment or Material Act (Act No. 7 of 2004).
Policy_Content: This Act regulates the use of farm equipment, i.e. any movables used for agricultural purposes on any agricultural land acquired for resettlement purposes under the Land Reform Programme, and provides for the control of use of farm equipment. Section 3 prohibits wilful destruction of farm equipment without the permission in writing of the acquiring authority (sect. 2). After the identification and valuation of farm equipment or material in terms of sections 4 and 5 of this Act, the acquiring authority may, if there is no agreement for the purchase of the farm equipment or material concerned, compulsorily acquire the farm equipment (sect. 7). Any farm equipment or material acquired in terms of this Act shall vest in the State for the benefit of the Land Reform Programme and shall not be sold or otherwise disposed of to any private individual, institution or corporation.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Land & soil

Policy: Shipping (Maritime Security) Regulations, 2004 (L.N. No. 5 of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations, made under the Merchant Shipping Act, introduce security measures for sea-going ships and port facilities and precautionary, control and compliance measures in relation to maritime safety. The Regulations implement provisions of the IMO International Management Code for the Safe Operation of Ships and for Pollution Prevention and the International Code for the Security of Ships and of Port Facilities. The Regulations shall apply to passenger ships, large cargo ships, including oil tankers and chemical tankers, mobile offshore drilling units and port facilities. The Minister shall set security levels and, when a security threat has been identified, advise the ships concerned of the current security level. Ships shall comply with security directions given. All ships shall have a security plan that shall be submitted to the Minister. Ships shall be provided with a ship security alert system.

Policy: Ozone in Ambient Air Regulations 2004 (S.I. No. 53 of 2004).

Policy: Forest Reproductive Material Regulations, 2004 (L.N. 273 of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations establish particular quality standards to be met by any forest reproductive material which is produced, placed on the market in Malta or transhipped through Malta prior to its transport to another Member State. The application scope encompasses forest reproductive material pertaining to the genera and species and artificial hybrids listed in Schedule I. Forest reproductive material which is destined to purposes other than forestry or intended to be exported or re-exported to third countries is excluded. A certification is required to produce, place on the market in Malta or tranship through Malta prior to its transport to another Member State any propagation material. If the basic material is genetically-modified within the meaning of Directive 2001/18/EC, such material shall only be accepted if it is safe for human health and the environment. Environmental risk assessments equivalent to that laid down in Directive 2001/18/EC should be carried out. A National Register of approved basic material shall be created (reg. 9). Further provisions regard the identification of reproductive material (reg. 10), official inspections (reg. 12), packaging (reg 15).

Policy: Law on fire safety.
Policy_Content: The present Law determines legal relations of state bodies, natural and legal persons irrespectively of the form of property in the sphere of ensuring fire safety on the territory of Turkmenistan. The Cabinet of Ministers shall establish general principles and certification in the sphere of fire safety (art. 17). Local executive bodies shall set up the commission for carrying out fire prevention and nature protection arrangements, ensuring fire safety and fire extinguishing in forest areas, mountain areas, steppe and grazing areas and shall organize the procedure thereof (art. 18). Policy_Content: Por la presente Ley se declara como política pública del Gobierno del Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico el desarrollo agrícola, la preservación y protección de los terrenos comprometidos con la Reserva Agrícola de Vega Baja localizada en el Municipio de Vega Baja. Policy: Regional Law No. 5-ZAO "On protection of the population and the territory against natural and technological disasters".
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates relations originating in the process of functioning of state bodies, local government, enterprises, institutions and organizations irrespectively of organizational and legal form thereof and the population, in the sphere of protection of the population and the territory against natural and technological disasters. It shall have the following purposes: (a) determination of the jurisdictional competence of state bodies, local government and organizations in the sphere of protection of the population and territory against natural and technological disasters with the consideration of geographic and climatic particulars of the regions; (b) prevention of the outbreak and propagation of disasters; (c) reduction of damages and losses caused by disasters; and (d) rehabilitation of the territory. Regional territorial subsystem of the national early warning system shall be responsible for data collection, processing and dissemination of the information related to disasters and timely information of the population thereof.

Policy: Swiss National Forest Programme (Swiss NFP) - Action Programme 2004–2015.
Policy_Content: The main objective of the present Swiss National Forest Programme is to guarantee the sustainable forest management and, as a precondition to this, to create favourable framework conditions for an efficient and innovative forest and wood sector. Moreover, with its vision (2030), concrete objectives (2015) and the corresponding strategic directions and measures, the Swiss National Forest Programme aims to optimize the three dimensions of sustainability and to improve the economic and social values of the forest as compared with the relatively high ecological value it already enjoys today. The successful elements of existing Swiss forest policy will continue to be implemented, others will be improved and new ones added. Thus, the changes in the environment of the forest and wood sector, the new challenges and the slow growth of the forest ecosystem will be taken into account.

Policy: Compact of Free Association, as Amended (Implementation) Act, 2004 (Title 41, Cap 1).
Policy_Content: This Act declares the Compact of Free Association between the United States of America and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, as amended, to have the force and effect of law as if enacted by the Nitijela. This Agreement concerns assistance of the United States and cooperation between the countries in matters of foreign affairs and other matters such as environmental protection. The conduct of foreign affairs relating to law of the sea and marine resources matters, including the harvesting, conservation, exploration or exploitation of living and non-living resources from the sea, seabed or subsoil to the full extent recognized under international law shall be included in the capacity to conduct foreign affairs of the Marshall Islands. As for environmental protection, the countries shall promote efforts to prevent or eliminate damage to the environment and biosphere and to enrich understanding of the natural resources of the Republic of the Marshall Islands. The United States shall for its military activities apply US environmental protection standards, policy and legislation. The Government of the Republic of the Marshall Islands shall continue to develop and implement standards and procedures to protect its environment.

Policy: National Gender and Children Policy.
Policy_Content: The National Gender and Children Policy is a national multi-sectoral policy for Ghana which was developed by the Ministry of Women and Children’s Affairs with the objective to mainstream gender concerns in the national development process in order to improve the social, civic, economic and cultural conditions of the people of Ghana, particularly women and children. Specific objectives of the Policy include: to redress imbalances which arise from existing gender inequalities through policy review, legal reforms and enforcement of existing legislation; to provide a national framework from which policies are derived; to implement activities designed to strengthen women’s role in the economic development; to implement activities designed to promote children’s development and protection; to promote women’s equal access to, and control over economically significant resources and benefits; and to enhance the survival, development and protection of children.

Policy_Content: Dans le cadre de mettre en œuvre la plate-forme d’action de Beijing singée lors de la quatrième Conférence Mondiale sur les Femmes en 1995, le Gouvernement Malgache a élaboré un Plan d’Action National Genre et Développement (PANAGED) qui reconnait la nécessité de promouvoir l’égalité des sexes et l’autonomisation des femmes, en tant que moyen efficace de combattre la pauvreté, la faim et la maladie et de promouvoir un développement réellement durable. Le Plan, dont l’exécution est prévue sur 5 ans (2004-2008), s’attache d’abord à intégrer transversalement la dimension genre dans toutes les interventions de développement. C’est l’objectif du «Programme principal d’intégration du genre dans les institutions, les programmes et projets de développement», qui comprend cinq composantes: la recherche-action, le plaidoyer, le renforcement des capacités, la communication et le suivi-évaluation.

Policy: Le Programme Forestier National.
Policy_Content: Suite à la Conférence des Nations Unies sur l’Environnement et le Développement (CNUED), qui s’est tenue à Rio de Janeiro en 1992, la France a élaboré son Programme forestier national (PFN) sur la base d’une approche participative. Le PFN a pour ambition de donner plus de lisibilité et plus de visibilité à l’action de la France dans ce domaine forestier, tant en métropole que dans les territoires d’outre-mer. Le Programme forestier national a pour objectif «de continuer à améliorer la gestion forestière et de contribuer au développement durable». Pour atteindre cet objectif, le Programme forestier national se décline en un ensemble d’orientations, notamment augmenter la mobilisation des bois et améliorer la transformation des produits forestiers pour développer l’emploi et créer des richesses (I); renforcer le poids et la compétitivité des industries de l’aval de la filière (II); accroître la contribution de la filière forêt-bois-papier à la lutte contre le changement climatique et accompagner le développement du bois énergie (III); promouvoir une gestion durable des forêts qui associe la production à la sauvegarde et à l’amélioration de la biodiversité (IV); et agir à différents niveaux (V).

Policy: Pipeline Regulation (Alta Reg, 91/2005).
Policy_Content: The present Regulation enforces the Pipeline Act. In particular, the Regulation lays down provisions relating to the design, construction, operation and maintenance including the discontinuation and abandonment of regulated pipelines. Moreover, the National Board’s inspection programme considers pipeline fluid characteristics, location, line size, failure history, and the company’s compliance history. Pipelines with greater potential risks are given a higher inspection priority. Furthermore, the Board requires licensees to develop and implement integrity management programmes to identify and mitigate risks associated with a particular pipeline, including corrosion mitigation and monitoring as well as other risk factors. Licensees must re-evaluate corrosion potential annually and keep records of the actions taken to ensure compliance with all regulations.

Policy: Land Re-Adjustment Act B.E. 2547 (2004).
Policy_Content: For the purpose of the present Act “land re-adjustment” means the implementation of development of many plots of land by land replotting, improving or constructing infrastructure, and jointly bearing the burdens and equitably distributing the returns. To this end, there shall be above all cooperation between the private sector and the public sector, with the objective of utilizing land more appropriately with regard to transportations, economics, social, the environment and communities, and so as to be in line with urban planning. Section 5 establishes the Land Readjustment Committee which has, inter alia, the following power and duties: 1) formulate policies, establish goals and important measures relating to Land Readjustment; 2) approve master plans and target areas for Land Readjustment; 3) establish standards for Land Readjustment; 4) issue regulations concerning criteria and procedures to be used in applying for land readjustment; 5) establish criteria and procedures for recruiting qualified Committee members; 6) Issue regulations governing the disbursement of the Fund in support of, or loans to, government agencies, etc.;7) conduct other activities involving land readjustment. Policy: Plan de gestion intégrée de la zone côtière de Djibouti.
Policy_Content: La zone côtière et ses ressources naturelles constituent un atout pour le développement économique de Djibouti. Toutefois, elle est de plus en plus menacée par les activités humaines.  Face à cette situation, un plan de gestion intégrée de la zone côtière a été élaboré afin d’assurer un développement harmonieux de la zone côtière qui permette à la fois le développement économique du pays, l’amélioration de sa compétitivité, la gestion durable des ressources naturelles, et l’amélioration des conditions de vie de la population. Pour atteindre ces objectifs, ce plan s’articule autour des cinq (5) buts majeurs suivants: l’Amélioration de la gestion des ressources en eau (But 1); la Maîtrise du développement économique de la zone côtière (But 2); la Maîtrise du développement urbain (But 3); la Meilleure gestion des déchets et lutte contre les pollutions (But 4); et la Préservation de l’environnement et des espèces marines et côtières (But 5).

Policy: Poverty Eradication Action Plan (2004-2008).
Policy_Content: The Poverty Eradication Action Plan (PEAP) provides an over-arching framework to guide public action to eradicate poverty. It has been prepared through a consultative process involving central and local Government, Parliament, Donors and Civil Society. In order to achieve middle-income status, Uganda needs to industrialise by enhancing its competitiveness. Industrialisation in Uganda will depend on using the resource base and hence on equipping farmers to understand the technical and quality requirements of commercial production. Government will therefore ensure the provision of public goods to support both agriculture and industry. In order to reverse the recent marked increase in inequality, Government will aim to increase the ability of the poorer households to participate in economic growth through self-employment inside and outside agriculture and wage employment. Gender issues arise under all pillars. In particular, the importance of addressing intra-household relations for agricultural productivity is emphasised. Discriminatory legislation is to be reviewed and reformed. The pattern of usage of services by gender is examined in various sectors. The shortage of fuelwood and its effect on women’s time use is strongly emphasised, as is the need for coordination between forestry and energy policy in addressing it. Women’s land rights need to be strengthened. Domestic violence is recognised as a problem and actions are being taken to reduce it.

Policy: Document de Stratégie Nationale de Microfinance (DSNMF) 2004-2009.
Policy_Content: La vision du Document de Stratégie Nationale de Microfinance (DSNMF) 2004-2009 est de : disposer d’un secteur de la microfinance, professionnel, viable et pérenne, intégré au secteur financier, diversifié et innovant, assurant une couverture satisfaisante de la demande du territoire et opérant dans un cadre légal, réglementaire, fiscal et institutionnel adapté et favorable. L’objectif de développement identifié est de favoriser l’accès à des services de microfinance viables et durables à une majorité des ménages pauvres ou à faibles revenus et des micro-entrepreneurs sur l’ensemble du territoire d’ici à 2009, grâce à des institutions de microfinance (IMF) viables s’intégrant dans le système financier national.  Pour atteindre cet objectif de développement, elle se fixe les objectifs immédiats suivants: le cadre économique, légal et réglementaire est amélioré dans un sens favorable à l’émergence et au développement des IMF; les IMF sont professionnelles et assurent de façon viable et pérenne une offre de produits et services de microfinance, adaptée, diversifiée et en augmentation, notamment dans les zones non encore couvertes ; le cadre institutionnel est organisé de manière à permettre une bonne structuration du secteur et la moralisation de la profession, une coordination efficace du secteur et la conduite efficiente et concertée de la SNMF et son articulation avec les autres politiques de développement. Le DSNMF s’articule autour de trois (3) axes stratégiques.

Policy: Stratégie Nationale d’Éducation et de Sensibilisation à l’Environnement et au Développement Durable (SN-ESE-DD), 2005-2014.
Policy_Content: La Stratégie Nationale d’Éducation et de Sensibilisation à l’Environnement et au Développement Durable (SN-ESE-DD) s'inscrit dans le cadre de la Décennie de l'éducation pour le développement durable (2005-2014) et contribue à appuyer la Stratégie Nationale de développement durable. L’Objectif global but ultime de la Stratégie Nationale d’Éducation et de Sensibilisation à l’Environnement et au Développement Durable (SN-ESE-DD) est de « contribuer à la mise en place à l'échelle nationale d'une culture environnementale citoyenne ».  L'objectif stratégique de la SN-ESE-DD est de convaincre les citoyens que sans environnement viable, il n'y aura pas de développement durable. Spécifiquement, la SN-ESE-DD vise à prodiguer une éducation environnementale harmonieuse et intégrée aux jeunes, dans tous les espaces d'éducation, de formation et de loisirs (Objectif spécifique 1); sensibiliser l'ensemble de la population à travers le pays aux enjeux environnementaux, dans la perspective d'un développement durable (Objectif spécifique 2); répondre aux besoins de renforcement des capacités des acteurs de l'éducation et de la sensibilisation en matière d'environnement (Objectif spécifique 3) pour contribuer à atteindre les deux objectifs précités (OS1 et OS2).

Policy: Corrupt Practices Act No 17 of 2004
Policy_Content: This act establishes the Anti-Corruption Bureau. The Bureau shall be a Government Department and the finances of the Bureau shall be charged to the Consolidated Fund. Policy: Plan fédéral pour l’intégration de la biodiversité dans 4 secteurs fédéraux clés.
Policy_Content: Le présent plan fédéral d’intégration sectorielle de la biodiversité a été établi en réponse à l’action 18, «Protéger la biodiversité», du 2ème Plan fédéral de développement durable 2004-2008 adopté par le gouvernement au conseil des ministres du 24 septembre 2004. Dans ce contexte, l’État fédéral propose d’élaborer des Plans d’action pour intégrer la diversité biologique au sein de quatre secteurs fédéraux clés, à savoir l’économie, la coopération au développement, la politique scientifique et le transport. Le document s’inscrit également dans le cadre de la mise en oeuvre de la Stratégie Nationale de la Belgique pour la Biodiversité. Le plan comprend quatre annexes qui correspondent respectivement au plan d’actions économie, coopération au développement, politique scientifique et transport. Ces annexes reprennent des fiches descriptives des actions d’intégration de la biodiversité dans le secteur concerné.

Policy: Prevention of Water Pollution - Usage of Sludge, Regulations (5764-2004).​
Policy_Content: These Regulations, by the Ministry of the Environment in collaboration with the Ministry of Health and the Water Council under the Water Law and other laws, aim to prevent water source pollution and environmental degradation as a result of improper disposal of sludge originating from municipal sewage treatment plants. The Regulations require wastewater treatment plants to stabilize and treat the sludge they generate as a condition for agricultural use or soil conditioning. They also establish maximum limits for heavy metal and pathogen concentrations and odor limits on sludge designated for agricultural use, set recording and laboratory testing requirements, define specific uses for different classes of sludge (A and B), set limitations on areas of sludge use, and prescribe requirements for warning signs, transport and storage.

Policy: Protection of the Coastal Environment Law 5764-2004 .
Policy_Content: This Law is aimed at: protecting the coastal environment, restoring and preserving coasts as a resource of unique value, and preventing and reducing as much as possible any damage to them; preserving the coastal environment and the coastal sand for the benefit and enjoyment of the public, for present and future generations; and establishing principles and limitations for the sustainable management, development and use of the coastal environment.   Under the law, sea and shore are considered one integral unit that extends from Israel's territorial waters to 300 meters inland. This entire area is considered a public resource which is to be preserved and protected from damage. The Law, among other things: Prohibits damage to the coastal environment; Assures an open public right of way along the entire length of the shore; Gives the Minister of Environmental Protection authority to impose a fee for the protection of the coastal environment on owners or holders of coastal facilities considered to cause damage to the coastal environment (which will be paid to the Maintenance of Cleanliness Fund); Gives the Minister of Environmental Protection authority to issue an order to prevent or remove environmental damage so as to restore the coastal environment to its former state; Gives the Minister of Environmental Protection authority to appoint inspectors to supervise the implementation of the law's provisions; Imposes severe penalties for coastal damage;  Establishes a Protection of the Coastal Environment Committee, which is responsible for decisions on coastal development plans, taking into account such considerations as preventing damage to the coastal environment, preserving the coast for public benefit, assuring public access to the coast, and conserving nature, landscape and heritage values. The Law also applies to the Sea of Galilee.

Policy: Cayman Islands National Policy on Gender Equity and Equality.
Policy_Content: National Policy on Gender Equity and Equality is a national policy with a multi-sectoral approach. The overall goal of this policy is to promote gender equality and sustainable human development in the Cayman Islands through good governance, fairness to both women and men, and equal status for both women and men in national development and the development of the society as a whole. Policy: Public Open Spaces By-law, 2004.
Policy_Content: This By-law of the City of Johannesburg Metropolitan Municipality concerns the management of public open spaces. The purpose of these By-laws is to provide, in conjunction with other applicable legislation, an effective legal and administrative framework to ensure that the way in which the Council controls, manages and develops public open spaces is environmentally sustainable, and is in the long-term interests of the whole community of Johannesburg, including future generations; and which clearly defines the rights and obligations of the public in relation to public open spaces. he natural environment and heritage resources within public open spaces must be identified, preservation. If the Council believes that any tree or group of trees in a public open space requires legal protection the Council may issue a tree preservation order in respect of that tree or group of trees. A tree preservation order must indicate the tree or trees to which it relates; and may provide that any person who cuts, disturbs, damages, destroys, removes, transports, exports, purchases, sells, donates or in any other manner acquires or disposes of the tree or trees to which it relates, commits an offence. No hunting or fishing may take place in public open spaces.

Policy: Regulation respecting halocarbons (CQLR c Q-2, r 29).
Policy_Content: The Regulation is organised in VII Chapters and 1 Schedule. The provisions of this Regulation apply to any halocarbon, whether existing alone or in a mixture, and to its isomers. The provisions of this Regulation do not apply to halocarbons used to spray a medication within the meaning of paragraph h of section 1 of the Pharmacy Act (chapter P-10) or a drug for which an identification number has been assigned under the Food and Drugs Act (R.S.C. 1985, c. F-27). They also do not apply to halocarbons, other than CFCs, used to spray substances other than those referred to in the second paragraph or to methyl bromide (CH3Br) when it is not used or intended to be used as a refrigerant. Only the provisions of sections 6 to 9, the first and second paragraphs of section 10, sections 14, 15, 57 and 58 and the provisions of Chapters III and IV apply to halocarbons that are used, have been used or are intended to be used for the operation of a household refrigeration or air conditioning unit. The provisions of this Regulation apply in a reserved area or an agricultural zone established under the Act respecting the preservation of agricultural land and agricultural activities (chapter P-41.1).

Policy: Presidential Decree No. 177/2004 validating the Regulation on the State Committee of Natural Resources.
Policy_Content: The State Committee of Natural Resources is the authorized central institution having plenary powers in the sphere of geological exploration, research and rational management of subsoil, and also topographic, geodetic and cartographic activity. The main tasks of the Committee are: 1) ensuring the realization of the state policy in the sphere of geological exploration, research and rational management of subsoil, and also topographic, geodetic and cartographic activity, ensuring the prospecting of mineral and raw material deposits, geological, hydro-geological and ecologic and geological exploration of subsoil,  carrying out state geological monitoring. The Committee, within its sphere of competence, shall carry out the following functions: 1) realization of common scientific research in the sphere of prospecting of minerals; 2) elaboration and validation of the regulations on exploration, prospecting and extraction of minerals; 3) registration and recording of scientific research of subsoil, and also topographic, geodetic and cartographic activity; 4) elaboration of the modalities of calculation of the rates of environmental fees for the use of subsoil and revenues to the state budget for access to geological, topographic and geodetic information; 5) carrying out state registration of groundwater; 6) issuing authorization (mining licences) for the management of mineral deposits.
Subject: Mineral resources

Policy: Presidential Decree No. 176/2004 validating the Regulation on the Ministry of Environmental Protection.
Policy_Content: The Ministry of Environmental Protection is the authorized central institution having plenary powers in the sphere of environmental protection, ecological safety, nature reserves, and also hydro-meteorological activity. The main tasks of the Ministry are: 1) ensuring the realization of the state policy in the sphere of environmental protection, rational use, replenishment and conservation of natural resources (land, surface water, atmospheric air, forest, wildlife and vegetable kingdom, resources of territorial sea, continental shelf and the EEZ of the Ukraine) carrying out environmental monitoring, management of waste, pesticides and agro-chemicals, ecological and radiation safety (within the proper sphere of competence), nature reserves management, formation of the national ecological network, and also hydro-meteorological activity, rational use on natural resources (except for subsoil). The Ministry, within its sphere of competence, shall carry out the following functions: 1) realization of common scientific research in the sphere of environmental protection; 2) organization and carrying out the state environmental audit; 3) issue of authorization for special nature management (except for subsoil), sets limits and quotas for disposal of waste and hazardous substances, and also rates of emissions and discharge of pollutants; 4) provides for keeping record and registration of wildlife and plant species and keeping state water cadastre; 5) conservation of natural landscapes and biological diversity;  6) organization of the ecological education of citizens.

Policy: Merchant Shipping (Prevention of Oil Pollution) (Amendment) Regulations 2004 (No. 303 of 2004).
Policy_Content: Regulation 4 of these Regulations implements amendments to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution at Sea 1973 as amended by its Protocol of 1978 ("MARPOL 73/78") which harmonize the survey and certification requirements of MARPOL 73/78 with the survey and certification requirements of the International Convention on the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS). Regulation 5 of these Regulations implements Regulation (EC) No. 417/2002 of the European Parliament and the Council of 18 February 2002 on the accelerated phasing-in of double hull or equivalent design requirements for single hull oil tankers and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2978/94. Regulation 5 restates the content of Regulation (EC) No. 417/2002, for the purposes of coherence. These Regulations are made under section 2(2) of the European Communities Act 1972(c. 68) in so far as they implement Regulation (EC) No. 417/2002. Regulation 6 of these Regulations implements amendments to MARPOL 73/78 which relate to the guidelines for development of shipboard oil pollution emergency plans, and makes provision for its combination with the shipboard marine pollution emergency plan for noxious liquid substances in the case of oil tankers where regulation 16 of Annex II to the Convention also applies. Regulation 7 of these Regulations amends provisions on the power to detain ships which do not comply with the requirements of the Regulations, and applies section 284(1) to (6) and (8) of the Merchant Shipping Act 1995.
Subject: Sea, Environment gen.

Policy: Act No. 36 laying down the new organization of the State Forestry Corps.
Policy_Content: The present Act lays down new provisions as to the organization of the State Forestry Corps, which is charged with special police functions in connection with the protection of the agricultural and forest heritage as well as the protection of the environment, landscape and ecosystems. Article 2 of the Act lists out the tasks which are entrusted to the Corps. They include in particular: (a) surveillance, prevention and punishment of offences in the field of environmental protection; (b) control and certification as regards the international marketing and keeping of fauna and flora specimens protected under the CITES Convention; (c) control of the effective implementation of international treaties concerning environmental matters, particularly those regarding the protection of forests and biodiversity; (d) surveillance of protected nature areas.

Policy_Content: Le présent arrêté du Gouvernement flamand porte la réglementation relative à l'inventaire, la récupération et l'élimination des halons. Policy: Regional Law No. 336-OZ “On some issues related to turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates relations concerning turnover of agricultural land within plenary powers pertaining to the jurisdictional competence of the regional administration. Privatization of agricultural land pertaining to regional state or municipal property shall begin from 1 January 2004. Minimum consolidated agricultural land plot area shall be two ha. Maximum agricultural land plot area that can be owned by a single household or by a single legal person within a single administrative unit shall vary from ten to seventy percent of total available agricultural land area within the boundaries of a single municipal unit. Regional administration and local government shall have preferential terms for purchase of agricultural land in case of sale thereof.

Policy: Ordonnance nº 04-001 portant Code minier.
Policy_Content: La présente ordonnance ainsi que les textes pris pour son application ont pour objet de régir les activités minières et de promouvoir les investissements dans le secteur minier en République Centrafricaine. Elle comprend 159 articles répartis en 10 titres, à savoir: Dispositions générales (I); Autorisations et titres miniers (II); Titres des carrières (III); Zones interdites et protégées, du règlement des litiges, de la protection de l’environnement (IV); Dispositions fiscales, douanières et financières (V); Conditions de la mise en valeur des pierres, métaux précieux et semi-précieux (VI); Agrément et du fonctionnement des bureaux et centres d’achat et des ateliers de transformation de pierres, métaux précieux, et semi précieux bruts (VII); Surveillance et contrôle administratif (VIII); Infractions et pénalités (IX) et  Dispositions transitoires et finales (X). Les dispositions du  Code visent à favoriser et à encourager la recherche, l’exploitation, la transformation et la commercialisation des ressources minérales nécessaires au développement économique et social du pays. Les dispositions de la présente ordonnance s’appliquent sur toute l’étendue du territoire de la République Centrafricaine. Les hydrocarbures liquides et gazeux relèvent des régimes particuliers définis par d’autres textes législatifs et réglementaires. Les personnes physiques ou morales désirant exercer une activité minière doivent, au préalable, obtenir une autorisation minière ou un titre minier délivré dans les conditions prévues par la présente ordonnance.  Les autorisations minières et les titres miniers sont consignés dans un registre dit registre des titres miniers, tenu par un conservateur.
Subject: Mineral resources
Geographical_area: Africa, AFRICA FAO, Central Africa, Landlocked Developing Countries, Least Developed Countries

Policy: Decree No. 21 of the Ministry of Taxes and Levies validating the Regulation on calculation and payment of land charges by legal persons.
Policy_Content: This Decree establishes calculation and payment of land charges by legal persons. Land charges shall be compulsory for all land tenants, including lessees and landowners except for cases envisaged by the national legislation. Land charges shall be collected in the form of land tax or rent for land plots allotted on lease to local self-government. The amount of land tax shall be set in accordance with quality and location of land plot and it shall not depend upon economic and other activities by land tenants and landowners. The amount of rent shall be set in accordance with lease contract and it cannot be lower than rates of land tax for the respective land category. Land tax shall be calculated as fixed annual payment per hectare. Land tax shall be subject to annual indexing in accordance with rates set by state budget for the current year.
Subject: Land & soil
Geographical_area: CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA

Policy: Solvent Emissions (Scotland) Regulations 2004 (S.S.I. No. 26 of 2004).
Policy_Content: These Regulations implement in Scotland the provisions of Council Directive 1999/13/EC on the limitation of emissions of volatile organic compounds due to the use of organic solvents in certain activities and installations. The Directive requires all installations carrying out activities listed in Annex I of the Directive above the thresholds in Annex IIA of the Directive to comply with certain emission limit values (SED installations). The majority of SED installations are already regulated under either the Pollution Prevention and Control (Scotland) Regulations 2000 (S.S.I. 2000/323) or Part 1 of the Environmental Protection Act 1990. As a result, these Regulations adjust the transitional provisions under the 2000 Regulations to align them with the requirements of the Directive.

Policy: Resolution No. 127 establishing an Environmental Affairs Department in all Syrian provinces.
Policy_Content: This Resolution provides for the establishment of an Environmental Affairs Department in all Syrian provinces. The Departments will be made up of the following offices: (a) Impact, Revising and Inspection Office, which shall include an EIA Branch, a Revising and Inspection Branch and a Licensing Branch; (b) Environmental Safety Office, which shall include a Water Safety Branch, a Land Safety Branch, a Chemical Safety and Waste Disposal Management Branch, an Air Safety Branch and a Biodiversity and Protected Zones Branch; (c) Office of Administrative, Legal and Finance Affairs which shall include a Statistics and Tracking Branch, a Laboratory Branch and an Internal Control Branch. Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 71 validating the Regulation on the width of the protective forest belt along the shorelines of rivers, lakes, water reservoirs and other waterbodies.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes the modalities for establishing the width of the protective forest belt along the shorelines of rivers, lakes, water reservoirs and other waterbodies. The protective forest belt shall be considered part of public forest adjoining the aforesaid water bodies, with restrictions on forest management in order to conserve water resources, prevent water pollution and siltation, and conserve the natural habitats of wildlife species. The width of the protective forest belt shall be established by the authorized forest institution in the process of forest organization and management, and shall take into consideration physical, geographic, soil, hydrological and other conditions, fisheries requirements and forest management projects.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 71 validating the Regulation on breadth of protection forest belt along riverside, banks of lakes, water reservoirs and waterbodies.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes breadth of protection forest belt along riverside, banks of lakes, water reservoirs and waterbodies and regulates the modalities of definition thereof. Protected forest belts shall be considered areas of public forest located along the aforesaid waterbodies with limited forest management with a view of conservation and concentration of water resources, pollution control, prevention of clogging and siltation of waterbodies, and also protection of habitats of wildlife species. In the rivers without flood bed the breadth of protection forest belt shall be calculated as average multiannual low water level. Minimum breadth for small rivers shall be up to 200 metres on each bank and 500 metres for rivers with favourable environmental conditions.

Policy: Planning and Urban Management Act 2004.
Policy_Content: This Act concerns the planning the use, development, management and protection of land in Samoa. One of the declared objectives (sect. 8) of this Act is to provide for the fair, orderly, economic and sustainable use, development and management of land including the protection of natural and man-made resources and the maintenance of ecological processes and genetic diversity. The Planning and Urban Management Agency is established under section 4 and the Planning and Urban Management Board under section 5. The functions of the Board are set out in section 9. Part IV of this Act makes provision for the preparation of Sustainable Management Plans, the contents of which are outlined in section 15. In relation to the carrying out of development, including any matter identified in a sustainable management plan, the Board may cause to be prepared and may approve a set of development standards in accordance with section 32. Part V and in particular section 42 concerns Environmental Impact Assessment. Development shall be authorized by the Agency. A Planning Tribunal is established under section 67 for purposes of this Act.

Policy_Content: The Region, in conjunction with the Provinces, Mountain Communities and Communes, shall promote the socioeconomic development of mountain areas. Afforestation intiatives shall be undertaken with a view to reducing CO2 in the atmosphere. Article 2 provides for the establishment of the Conference for Mountains. Article 8 defines the content of the programme to be adopted by the regional authority to pursue the development of mountain areas. The interventions hereby envisaged shall be financed through the Regional Fund for Mountain referred to in article 11. The subsidies indicated in article 17 shall be granted to small farmers.

Policy: Ministerial Joint Decree No. 125347/568 establishing Codes of Good Agricultural Practice.
Policy_Content: With the purpose of addressing issues related to agricultural activities and providing good management practice on how to avoid polluting water, air and soil, this Decree establishes certain practices to be applied by farmers and others involved in agricultural activities, named Codes of Good Agricultural Practice. The Codes aim at: the sustainable management of agricultural lands and natural resources, the protection and safeguarding of rural landscape and its specific characteristics, farmers and consumers health protection. For the achievement of the afore-mentioned objectives, the Codes intervene in the following agricultural activities (Chapter A, articles 1-9): ground treatment; shifting cultivation, crop rotation system; fertilization; management of water resources; plant protection; management of autochthonous flora; crop harvesting; management of crop surplus; waste management. Shifting cultivation regards only the annual, arable and horticulture crops. All other activities mentioned concern all types of crops. The Codes of Good Agricultural Practice concern, also, the following stock breeding activities (Chapter B, articles 10-13): pasture lands management; animal welfare; management of waste of animal origin. Moreover, regarding certain regions or areas mentioned in Chapter C “Special cases” (articles 14-16), additional Codes shall apply. The last Chapter D (articles 17-21) deals with the implementation of the Codes, controls and sanctions.
