Policy: Order No. 26 of the Ministry of Fuel and Energy validating the Regulation on the modalities of compilation of the act of ecological, emergency and technological protection of the consumer of the consumer of electric energy.
Policy_Content: Ecological protection of the consumer of electric power is the minimum level of consumption of electric energy by the consumer (except for the population) ensuring prerequisites for the prevention of the originating of natural and technological disasters. Ecological protection of electric energy supply shall be set for the consumers whose objects are included in the register of consumers for which ecological protection is compulsory. The consumers included in the register must conform electric energy supply schemes to the requirements set for the respective categories (I or II) as regards reliability of electric energy supply. Protection of electric energy supply against emergencies shall ensure protection against negative consequences of technological and environmental disasters. Act of ecological, emergency and technological protection is the official document of the established form filled in conformity with the present Regulation that contains data regarding consumer, the list of current collectors subject to ecological, emergency and technological protection, specifying load thereof daily consumption of electric energy and the time of the conclusion of technological process. The Regulation establishes the modalities of calculation of the level of environmental protection for the purpose of ecological certification of the power supply plants.

Policy: Law of the Republic of Armenia on the Regulatory Body for Public Services.
Policy_Content: This Law specifies the procedure for the establishment of the regulatory body for public services and its operation (art. 1). Regulated Sector of Public Utility includes the following: a) the energy sector, including the electric energy, heat supply and gas supply systems; b) the water sector, including the potable water, irrigation water and technical water supply, drainage and wastewater treatment (art. 2). Regulation in Public Utility Sector is a part of the state policy aimed at the balancing of the interests between the consumers and the entities operating in the Public Utility, exercising its rights and responsibilities pursuant to the laws, creation of equitable conditions for operation of the Regulated Entities and effective use of resources (art. 4). The basic principles of regulation shall be as follows: a) regulation by the independent state body; b) collegiality of decision making; c) transparency of regulation for the public; d) exclusion of any discrimination towards the consumers or any Regulated Entity; e) balancing of interests between the consumers and the Regulated Entities; f) reduction of regulation framework (art. 5).

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 45 validating the Regulation on forest management.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree regulates forest management of the state forest fund. Forest management shall be carried out in accordance with common scheme established by the authorized forest institution. The purpose of forest management shall be to ensure the annual renewal of forest management projects of public forest owners. In the process of forest management shall be carried out the following arrangements: (a) inventory; (b) mapping; (c) registration of forest resources; and (d) monitoring. Forest management shall cover the period of three years and shall be carried out in three stages: (a) preparatory (the first year); (b) field (the second year) and (c) cameral (the third year).

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 32 validating the Regulation on call for tenders for the allotment of plots of public forest for long-term forest management.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes the modalities of carrying out call for tenders for the allotment of plots of public forest for long-term forest management. It shall not be applicable to forest resources located on protected areas. Plots of public forest envisaging one or more types of forest management by a single forest user shall be allotted thereto through tenders. Forest management shall be considered timber extraction and hunting. Plots of public forest shall be allotted for the following periods: (a) timber extraction – 10 to 49 years; (b) procurement of soft resin and wood spirit – 10 to 15 years; (c) hunting – 10 to 49 years; and (d) recreation, tourism and sport – 10 to 49 years.

Policy: Barbados National Sustainable Development Policy.
Policy_Content: The National Sustainable Development (NSD) Policy is a product of the National Commission on Sustainable Development (NCSD). The formulation of the NSD Policy is envisaged as one component of a new approach to Sustainable Development in Barbados, one which aims to deal with individual issues from an integrated and holistic perspective. The goal is the pursuit of Sustainable Development by all sectors, groups and individuals in Barbados. The aim of the policy is to sensitize all persons about the need to make wise choices daily, at the individual, household, business, community and national levels because these choices affect our national development. This policy therefore is not intended to be a blueprint for sustainability. Rather this policy is intended to provide guidelines and a pragmatic framework that facilitates decision-making at the level where costs and benefits accrue whether it is at the national, corporate or individual level. Recognising that Sustainable Development requires the full involvement and integration of all persons into the development process; and that all forms of gender-based discrimination must be eliminated. The Commission recommends: Development of a broad gender perspective at all levels of education; The development of curricula in gender studies for all teachers; The harmonisation of legal reforms geared towards eliminating gender discrimination (19).

Policy: Regional Law No. 200 “On turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates relations concerning ownership, tenure and disposal of plots agricultural land and also land share in common property. Maximum agricultural land plot area that can be owned by a single household of by a single legal person within a single administrative unit shall not exceed ten percent of total available agricultural land area. It also establishes that minimum agricultural land plot authorized for allotment for agricultural production shall be established within average allotment rate set forth for each municipal district. Policy: Law No. 262-Z on technical regulation and standardization.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates relations regarding norm-setting and application of technical requirements to produce, manufacturing, transport, storage and use thereof, and ensures carrying out common state policy in the aforesaid sphere. The purpose of the Law shall be to ensure the application of technical norms and standards to the produce in order to render it safe for human life and environment, and also to make it comply with environmental standards. The Act consists of five Sections divided into 31 articles: (1) general provisions; (2) state regulation of technical norm-setting and standardization; (3) requirements for the application of technical norms and standards; (4) international cooperation; and (5) conclusive provisions. The scope of standardization shall be to ensure: (a) safety of human life and health; (b) environmental protection, rational management of natural resources and energy saving; and (c) prevention of the circulation of misleading information as regards quality and safety of produce.
Subject: Environment gen., Food & nutrition
Geographical_area: CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA

Policy: Law No. 269-Z on evaluation of compliance with technical norms and standards.
Policy_Content: This Law establishes legal and organizational grounds for carrying out evaluation of compliance with technical norms and standards for the purpose of ensuring common state policy in the sphere of evaluation of compliance. The Act consists of six Sections divided into 41 articles: (1) general provisions; (2) state regulation and management in the sphere of evaluation of compliance; (3) accrediting; (4) attesting of compliance; (5) international cooperation; and (6) conclusive provisions. The purpose of the evaluation of compliance shall be protection of human life and environment. The objects of evaluation shall be produce and environmental management system. The state regulation shall include: (a) elaboration and implementation of common state policy; (b) coordination of evaluation proceedings; (c) establishment of common rules and procedures for evaluation practices; and (d) validation of the list of produce and objects for the evaluation. Attestation of evaluation shall be carried out in the following forms: (a) compulsory certification; (b) declaration of compliance; and (c) voluntary certification.

Policy: Regional Law No. 111 “On the particulars of turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates relations concerning ownership, land tenure, and disposal of agricultural land. Policy: Regional Law No. 656-KZ “On protected areas”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates relations, originating in the sphere of organization, conservation and protection of protected areas with a view of conservation of unique and typical ecosystems and complexes, wild fauna and wild flora species, and control of changes in the state of biosphere. Protected areas shall be classified as follows: (a) natural parks; (b) nature monuments; (c) dendrological parks and botanical gardens; and (d) healthcare areas and spas. Protected areas shall be constituted by decision of the supreme executive body of the Regional Administration upon recommendation by the authorized state institution in the sphere of environmental protection. Protected areas shall be subject to mandatory registration in the State Register of protected areas. Natural parks shall have the status of recreational environmental protection institutions. Territory under natural parks shall be allotted thereto on condition of open-ended (permanent) land tenure.

Policy: Geographical Indications Act No. 21 of 2003.
Policy_Content: This Act lays down rules for the protection of the geographical indications of any natural or agricultural product or any product of handicraft or industry. In accordance with the provisions of this Act, any interested person and any group of producers or consumers may institute proceedings in the Court to prevent (I) the use of any means in the designation or presentation of a good that misleads the public as to the geographical origin of the good; (II) any use which constitutes an act of unfair competition; and (III) use of a geographical indication identifying wines for wines not originating in the place indicated by the geographical indication in question. The protection under this Act shall be available regardless of whether a geographical indication has been registered. This Act sets forth provisions on the conditions for the availability of protection and exclusion from protection; procedures and principles of the registration of a geographical indications; right to use a registered geographical indication; cancellation and rectification of the registration of a geographical indication; refusal or invalidation of the registration of a trademark which contains misleading marks; and competence of courts. The Minister may make regulations prescribing all matters that are    necessary or convenient for giving effect to the purposes of this Act. Nothing in this Act shall apply in respect of a geographical indication of any country with respect to goods or services for which the relevant indication is identical with the term customary in common language as the common name for such goods or services in Antigua and Barbuda; or a geographical indication of any other country with respect to products of the vine for which the relevant indication is identical with the customary name of a grape variety existing in Antigua and Barbuda as of January 1st, 1995.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development

Policy: Ministerial Decree No.794 regarding common state system of the prevention and liquidation of emergencies.
Policy_Content: The Government decrees to validate the Regulation on common state system of the prevention and liquidation of emergencies. The present Regulation establishes the modalities of organization and functioning of common state system of prevention and liquidation of emergencies. Common system unites managing bodies, forces and means of the federal executive bodies, regional executive bodies, local self-government and organizations which competence consists in the solution of issues in the sphere of protection of population and territories against emergencies. Coordinating bodies, permanent managing bodies, bodies of everyday management, forces and means, financial and material reserves, communication systems, early warning systems and information systems are set up at each level of common system. The main arrangements carried out by managing bodies and forces of common system are: 1) study of the state of environment and forecasting of emergencies; 2) data collection, processing and exchange of information in the field of protection of the population and territories against emergencies and ensuring fire prevention; 3) elaboration and realization of special and scientific and technical programs and arrangements for the prevention of emergencies and ensuring fire prevention. Liquidation of transboundary emergencies is carried out by decision of the Government in accordance with international agreements of the Russian Federation.
Subject: Environment gen.

Policy: Regional Law No. 185 “On forest management, conservation, protection and reproduction of forests growing on urban land”.
Policy_Content: The scope of this Regional Law shall be management, conservation, protection and reproduction of forests located on urban land. Urban forests shall be registered within the boundaries of urban areas and shall be destined for recreation of the population and conservation of favourable environment. Urban forest shall not be included in state forest fund, but shall be classified as public forest managed by regional administration. Urban forests shall be mapped and separated by boundaries form construction and residential areas. Urban forests can be used for the following purposes: (a) recreation, tourism, sport and cultural activity; (b) scientific research; (c) timber extraction in the process of sanitary felling and miscellaneous felling; (d) procurement and collection of non-timber (edible and non-edible) products. Hunting, timber extraction, procurement of rare and protected non-timber products recorded in the Red Book, and illegal felling in urban forests shall be prohibited.

Policy: Regional Law No. 90-KZ “On regulation of land relations”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates land relations on the regional territory of the within the powers granted to the constituent entities of the Russian Federation by federal legislation. The objects of land relations are land as a natural object and natural resource, land plots, parts of land plots. Participants in land relations are the Russian Federation, regional administration, municipalities, citizens and legal entities, including land owners, participants in shared ownership, land users, landowners, tenants, and servitude owners. Land in the region shall be classified into the following categories for their intended purpose: (a) agricultural land; (b) urban land; (c) land of industry, energy, transport, communications, radio broadcasting, television, informatics, land for space activities, defense land and land for other special purposes; (c) land of protected areas; (d) land of the forest fund; (e) land of the water fund; and (f) reserve land. Transfer of land from one category to another shall be performed by regional executive and by local government in accordance with their respective competences. Land plots in state or municipal ownership, in addition to cases established by federal legislation, shall be allotted once free of charge to the ownership of citizens of the Russian Federation residing in the regional territory in the following cases: (a) for activities of a peasant (farm) to citizens permanently residing in the municipality, on the territory of which it is planned to carry out its activities of the peasant (farm) economy to large families; and (b) for gardening, truck farming, animal husbandry, suburban construction, peri-urban agriculture, personal subsidiary small-holding (at the choice of the citizen): to vulnerable groups of the population, protected categories of the population and to persons with special merits for services to the state.

Policy: Local Government Service Act, 2003 (No. 656).
Policy_Content: This Act provides for the Local Government Service in conformity with article 190 of the Constitution. The Service shall consist of non-elected officers of the local administration including Regional Coordinating Councils and District Assemblies. The object of the Service is to secure the effective administration and management of local government in the country. It shall provide technical assistance to District Assemblies, and Regional Coordinating Councils. The Service shall be governed by the Local Government Service Council. There shall be also a secretariat and a Head of the Service. The Act also provides with respect to the organization of the public administration at regional and district level.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Geographical_area: Africa, North Atlantic, Western Africa

Policy: Law No. 3208/2003. Protection of forest ecosystems, regulation of rights over forests and forestal areas and other provisions.
Policy_Content: The law provides for a wide range of matters regarding forest ecosystems, rights over forests and forestal areas, environmental protection. It also makes extensive amendments to a number of other legislative texts. Article 2 of the Law makes provisions for the protection of the landscape and biodiversity. It is mentioned that the planning of management and exploitation of forest ecosystems have to ensure the protection of landscape and the conservation of biodiversity. In this framework, the creation of agrobiotopes by environmental organizations and owners of agricultural land is supported financially. The procedure for constituting a Forest Inventory is described in article 3 of the law. The inventory will be based on the type of forest vegetation. The competent bodies are appointed in the same article. In article 8 is defined the procedure for financing the works and activities for development, exploitation and protection of the forest and hunting resources of the country. According to paragraph 1, article 19 of the law, and for the purposes of environmental protection and promotion of the national economy, those forests whose management and exploitation has been abandoned over the past twenty years shall come under the management of the competent Forest Authority. Paragraph 3 of this article establishes working groups consisting of specialist scientists for the constitution of the Greek Standards for timber and the rest forest products of primary production, as well as the products of their primary processing. Moreover, it is decided to determine the procedure and the definition of the conditions for the establishment of a mark and the issue of a quality certificate. In paragraph 6 of this article is given provision for three-months’ training on the subject of forest protection for forest rangers, forest protection employees and technical drivers. In the same article, paragraph 11 states that all duties concerning leasing marine sites, renewing lease, issuing License for Project Establishment and Operation to aquaculture farms is devolved to the General Secretariat of the respective Region (which is the competent regional authority of the Ministry of Rural Development and Food). The establishment of offices and positions for the implementation of the Convention on international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora (CITES Convention) is arranged under article 20 of the law. More specifically, a Department entitled “International Conventions” is established and shall be responsible for the supervision and the implementation of the Convention and the issue of the relevant permits to the Greek State. The new Department shall fall under the competency of the Administration of Aesthetic Forests, National Parks and Hunting of the Ministry of Rural Development and Food, which is appointed as the Central Administrative Authority. Respectively, in regional forest administrations are established offices entitled «International Conventions’», which are assigned to the aforementioned administration and the relevant positions are created.
Subject: Fisheries, Forestry

Policy: Council Directive 2003/122/Euratom on the control of high-activity sealed radioactive sources and orphan sources.
Policy_Content: The aim of this Directive is to prevent exposure of workers and the public to ionizing radiation arising from inadequate control of high-activity sealed radioactive sources and orphan sources and to harmonize controls in place in the Member States. The Directive defines specific requirements ensuring that each such source is kept under control. These provisions apply to high-activity sources, which are defined under article 2 as sealed sources containing a radionuclide whose activity at the time of manufacture or, if this is not known, of the first placing on the market is equal to or exceeds the relevant activity level specified in Annex I. Any practice involving a source (including taking possession of a source) shall be subject to prior authorization.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 1286 validating the Regulation on the use of public forests for recreational, cultural and tourism purposes.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree regulates certain aspects of managing forests used for recreational, cultural and tourism purposes. It applies to all public forests except for protected areas. Use restrictions may be imposed during periods of forest fire risk. Forest management for the aforesaid purposes shall be carried out in accordance with contracts. Forest managers must: (a) observe fire regulations; (b) prevent pollution, protect trees and shrubbery from felling or damage, prevent damage to ant hills and bird nests; (b) collect non-timber products within established periods and by authorized methods; and (c) observe forest legislation.

Policy: : Ministerial Decree No. 1287 validating the Regulation on the trade of standing timber.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree regulates main use felling, intermediate felling and other types of standing timber extraction in public forests. It also applies to protected forests with the consideration of the purposeful use thereof. Main use felling shall target mature and overly-mature timber, as well as plantations damaged by forest fires, pests, wind and pollutants. Intermediate felling (thinning operations, selective felling and sanitary felling) shall target timber of little value, single trees in young forests and protected forests that have lost protection properties. Timber extraction shall require a forestry licence.

Policy: Decree-Law No. 320/2003 introducing in the National legal order the Directive 2002/3/EC of the European Parliament and Council related to the ozone in the atmosphere.
Policy_Content: This Decree-Law introduces in the National legal order the Directive 2002/3/EC of the EU Parliament and the Council relating to ozone in the atmosphere. The Decree-Law establishes long term objectives, target values, an alert threshold and an information threshold for concentrations of ozone in the atmosphere in the Community as well as air quality managing rules. The aim of the Decree-Law is to preserve the quality and to promote the improvement of air with regards to ozone. It also aims to boost cooperation between Member States in order to prevent the reduction of ozone levels, taking advantage of the potential of transboundary measures. The Decree-Law is composed of 14 articles and the following eight Annexes: (I) Definitions, target values and long-term objectives for ozone; (II) Information and alert thresholds; (III) Information submitted by Member States to the Commission and criteria for aggregating data and calculating statistical parameters; (IV) Criteria for classifying and locating, sampling points for assessments of ozone concentrations; (V) Criteria for determining the minimum number of sampling points for fixed measurement of concentrations of ozone; (VI) Measurement of ozone precursor substances; (VII) Data quality objectives and compilation of the result of air quality assessment; (VIII) Reference method for analysis of ozone and calibration of ozone instruments.
Subject: Air & atmosphere

Policy: Arrêté du Gouvernement flamand fixant la valeur limite et la valeur guide pour les résidus de nitrates, en exécution de l'article 13bis, § 1er, et les conditions d'octroi d'une dérogation aux normes de fertilisation et aux conditions de fertilisation dans les zones vulnérables "eaux", en exécution de l'article 15, §§ 8 et 9 et de l'article 17 du décret du 23 janvier 1991 relatif à la protection de l'environnement contre la pollution due aux engrais.
Policy_Content: L’arrêté susmentionné du Gouvernement flamand fixe la valeur limite et la valeur guide pour les résidus de nitrates, en exécution de l'article 13bis, paragraphe 1er, et les conditions d'octroi d'une dérogation aux normes de fertilisation et aux conditions de fertilisation dans les zones vulnérables "eaux", en exécution de l'article 15, paragraphes 8 et 9 et de l'article 17 du décret du 23 janvier 1991 relatif à la protection de l'environnement contre la pollution due aux engrais. L’article 2 établit que la dérogation générale est uniquement octroyée à celui qui fait la déclaration, conformément à l'article 3, paragraphes 1er et 6 du décret susvisé. Le demandeur de la dérogation générale doit faire la déclaration du plan de culture, visé à l'article 3, paragraphe 1er, 3° du décret et l'indication sur du matériel cartographique, conformément à l'article 3, paragraphe 1er, 5° du décret, de manière complète et définitive, pour toutes les parcelles de terres arables utilisées par lui, avant le 1er mai de l'année de production dans laquelle il désire avoir recours à la dérogation générale. Le texte comprend 12 articles et 1 annexe.
Subject: Land & soil, Cultivated plants
Geographical_area: Benelux, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, North Atlantic, North Sea, North-East Atlantic, Western Europe
Entry into force notes: Le présent arrêté entre en vigueur le 1er février 2003.

Policy: Arrêté ministériel relatif à l'octroi de subventions au semis d'un couvert végétal, en application du Programme flamand pour le Développement rural.

La partie initiale contient la définition de certains termes comme, par exemple, «déclaration de superficie», «division», «ALP», «couvert végétal», «producteur». Le texte comprend 13 articles répartis en 5 chapitres comme suit: Dispositions générales relatives à l'engagement (Ier); Conditions de subventionnement (II); Procédure de paiement (III); Suivi de l'état d'avancement du dossier et contrôle (IV);- Dispositions finales (V). Une annexe est jointe.

Policy: Arrêté ministériel relatif à l'octroi de subventions à la production sur l'exploitation de sources de protéines végétales en application du Programme flamand pour le Développement rural.
Policy_Content: Le présent arrêté ministériel porte la réglementation relative à l'octroi de subventions à la production sur l'exploitation de sources de protéines végétales en application du Programme flamand pour le Développement rural. A ce propos l’article 2 établit que le producteur qui exploite un élevage de bétail comptant des ruminants et s'engage à produire chaque année pendant au moins cinq années consécutives, au minimum 0,5 ha de sources de protéines végétales, peut bénéficier d'une subvention annuelle de 600 euros par hectare. Le texte comprend 12 articles répartis en 5 chapitres comme suit: Dispositions générales relatives à l'engagement (Ier); Conditions de subventionnement (II); Procédure de demande et de paiement (III); Suivi de l'état d'avancement du dossier et contrôle (IV);. Policy: Arrêté ministériel concernant l'octroi de subventions pour la protection de la diversité génétique de vergers à hautes tiges, en application du Programme flamand de Développement rural.
Policy_Content: Le présent arrêté ministériel porte la réglementation relative à l'octroi de subventions pour la protection de la diversité génétique de vergers à hautes tiges, en application du Programme flamand de Développement rural. L’article 2 établit que l'agriculteur qui s'engage à planter des arbres fruitiers à hautes tiges des variétés reprises dans la liste en annexe, et à les maintenir et entretenir pendant cinq ans, peut bénéficier d'une subvention annuelle de 4 euros par arbre pendant cinq ans. Tandis que l’agriculteur qui s'engage à maintenir et entretenir pendant cinq années consécutives des arbres fruitiers à hautes tiges existants des variétés reprises dans la liste en annexe, peut bénéficier d'une subvention annuelle de 2 euros par arbre pendant cinq ans. Le texte comprend 15 articles répartis en 6 chapitres comme suit: Définitions (Ier); Dispositions générales relatives à l'engagement (II); Agrément d'associations (III); Les obligations des associations agréées (IV); Suivi de l'état d'avancement et contrôle (V); Dispositions finales (VI). Une annexe est jointe.

Policy: Act on Verification and Notification of Origin of Electricity (19.12.2003/1129).
Policy_Content: This Act provides for the certification of origin of electricity-produced commodities from renewable energy sources and high-efficiency generation of electricity. An electricity supplier shall, at least once each calendar year, produce electricity invoices or attachments, and refer to public sources of information where there is data on the amount of carbon dioxide emissions and radioactive waste generated by energy sources for electricity sold during the previous calendar year. Certification of origin as a State of the European Union (EU) or European Economic Area (EEA) States for electricity produced commodities from renewable energy sources shall be recognized in accordance to EU provisions. The Energy Market Authority has the task of monitoring compliance with this Act.  Notwithstanding this Act or regulations issued under it, marketing legality is also monitored under the Consumer Protection Act (38/1978).
Subject: Energy

Policy: Regional Law No. 976-OZ “On turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates allotment of agricultural land parcels pertaining to public or municipal property and establishes minimum and maximum dimensions of the aforesaid parcels. Maximum land area of agricultural land parcel owned by a single natural or legal person shall not exceed 20 percent of the total agricultural land area within the boundaries of a given municipal unit. Minimum lease period of agricultural land shall be established as follows: (a) for seed growing – 3 years; (b) for gardening – 2 years; for floriculture, horticulture, scientific research and educational purposes – 1 year.

Policy: Regional Law No. 65-OZ on turnover of agricultural land.
Policy_Content: Privatization of agricultural land belonging to state or municipal property on the regional territory begins from the date of entry into force of the present Regional Law. Minimum size for the newly formed plots of agricultural land for grain production is 300 hectares, for other agricultural purposes is 1 hectare. The Regional Law consists of 9 Articles. Article 1 determines the beginning of the privatization of agricultural land. Article 2 establishes the utmost size of the plots of agricultural land on the regional territory. Article 3 determines the modalities of purchase and trade of the plots of land and land shares in common property of agricultural land. Article 4 envisages the cases of concession on lease or into ownership of the plots of land out of the stock of land destined for re-distribution to physical or juridical persons with or without compensation. Article 5 determines the conditions and the modalities of expropriation of the plots of agricultural land in case of its improper use. Article 6 regards financial backing of the turnover of agricultural land on the regional territory. Article 7 regards media coverage of the turnover of agricultural land on the regional territory. Article 8 lays down the final provisions. Article 9 determines the modalities of entry into force of the present Regional Law.

Policy: Act on Nature Conservation (No. 29 of 2003).
Policy_Content: This Act sets regulatios on the protection of the environment in Greenland. It applies to wildlife consisting of mammals, birds and other animals as well as to wild plants, including aquatic plants. It does not include fish or clams, shrimps or other invertebrates that live in salt and fresh water. Conservation methods of mammals and birds are specified based on their gender and size where quota, methods and season of allowed catch are specified accordingly. The Act also sets restrictions regarding the catch of other animals and the collection of wild plants. The Government has the power to make decisions on suspension of conservation restrictions as long as cases are agreed by local authorities and institutions. Expropriation may also occur, if required for conservational purposes. Salt lakes and heat sources also fall under the protection of the environment.

Ce chapitre est divisé en 3 sections, c’est-à-dire Paquet de gestion axé sur la restauration, le développement et l'entretien d'éléments paysagers ligneux (1re). Ce dernier chapitre comprend 7 sections comme suit: Paquet de gestion axé sur la prairie, fauchage à partir du 16 juin (1er); Paquet de gestion axé sur la prairie, fauchage à partir du 1er juin (2); Paquet de gestion axé sur la prairie, pâturage à partir du 16 juin (3); Paquet de gestion axé sur la prairie, pâturage à partir du 1er juin (4);Paquet de gestion axé sur les terres arables, pleins champs (5); Paquet de gestion axé sur les terres arables, lisière (6); Dispositions communes relatives aux paquets de gestion sur l'objectif de gestion axé sur la gestion botanique (7); Les contrats de gestion (VII); Suivi et contrôle (VIII); Dispositions transitoires et finales (IX). Policy: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading Scheme Regulations 2003 (S.I. No. 3311 of 2003).
Policy_Content: The Regulations control emissions of carbon dioxide from any of the activities listed in Schedule 1 to the Regulations. Part 2 of Schedule 1 sets out rules for the interpretation of Part 1 of Schedule 1. Part 1 of the Regulations (regs. 1 to 6) sets out general provisions. Regulation 2 contains definitions including designating the regulators for installations under the scheme. The other regulations in Part 1 deal with general matters such as the service of notices under the Regulations. Part 2 deals with the need for a permit to operate an installation covered by the Regulations (reg. 7), the procedure for granting permits and the contents of permits (regs. 8 to 10), and the treatment of permits once granted (regs. 12 to 16). The conditions of permits (reg. 10) must ensure that the emissions of the installation are properly monitored and reported and that the operator surrenders within 4 months of the end of each scheme year allowances equal to the annual reportable emissions from the installation during that year. Part 3 deals with the allocation of allowances. Part 4 (regs. 22 to 25) contains the enforcement powers under the Regulations. Part 5 (regs. 26 to 28) and Schedules 2 to 4 provide for appeals against decisions of the regulator and for appeals for the appropriate authority, responsible authority or the Secretary of State to reconsider decisions under the Regulations. Part 6 (regs. 29 to 31) sets out information gathering powers and publicity requirements. Part 7 (regs. 32 to 35) sets out offences for contraventions of the Regulations and civil penalties where an operator fails to surrender sufficient allowances to cover its specified emissions. Part 8 (regs. 36 to 37) enables the appropriate authority to give directions and guidance to regulators. Part 9 (reg. 38) and Schedule 5 deal with consequential amendments required by the introduction of the emissions trading scheme in the Regulations.
Subject: Air & atmosphere
Geographical_area: Atlantic Ocean Islands, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, North Atlantic, North Sea, North-East Atlantic, Northern Europe

Policy: Australian Heritage Council Regulations 2003 (SR No. 353 of 2003).
Policy_Content: The Council must keep a register of places in the Australian jurisdiction and their heritage values (‘Register of the National Estate’) in accordance with the Act and these Regulations and Regulations. If the Australian Heritage Council proposes to include a place in, or remove a place from, the Register of the National Estate, it must: (a) inform the appropriate authority of the State or Territory government and the local government (if any) of all or part of the place about the proposal; and (b) give the authority a reasonable opportunity to comment on the proposal. If the Council includes a place in, or removes a place from, the Register, it must inform the appropriate authority of the State or Territory government and the local government (if any) of all or part of the place about the decision. The Register of the National Estate shall be kept in accordance with rules laid down in regulation 5.

Policy_Content: Article 8 shall be amended to add the following wording: “Public land shall be sold to gardeners' associations, members of these association and other persons according to the procedure established by the Government. Land for artisanal gardening within gardening associations required for the layout and recreation of common use buildings shall be subject to sale. For natural persons, land parcels used by them are not auctioned in the territory of an artisanal gardening associations. In cases where it is not possible to form a separate plot of land for the needs of gardeners' associations for the purpose of changing or supplementing the land use plan or other spatial planning document of the artisanal gardening area, it is primarily sold by auction to the owners of the parcels directly adjacent to the plot of land intended for sale.” Article 9 shall be amended to add the following wording: “Land parcels sold to members of gardeners' associations and other users of gardening land plots in the territory of an artisanal gardening association shall be formed according to the land use plan or other spatial planning document and shall not exceed 0.12 ha, unless the land is sold in accordance with the procedure and conditions specified in Article 8 (7) of this Law.”

Policy_Content: The Act aims to establish a framework for the protection of surface water and groundwater, as well as its planning within the environment internationally protected areas. Policy: Ordinance on the National Park „Kellerwald-Edersee“.
Policy_Content: The present Law implements the Hessen Nature Protection Law in its version of 16 April 1996. The Law establishes the National Park ”Kellerwald-Edersee”. Article 2 lays down provisions relating to surface description and demarcation of the National Park. In particular, the purpose of the National Park is to: 1) conserve the natural and semi-natural ecosystems with their typical plants and animal habitats, as well as the minerals and the soil; 2) conserve the natural symbiosis of plants and animals; 3) conserve and restore the natural beauty and cultural heritage of the landscape; 4) study the ecosystems and habitats; 5) make the area accessible to the population for recreational purposes. Articles 10 and 11 establish respectively a National Park Office and a National Park Advisory Board responsible the former for the planning and management and the latter for consultancy and support of the Park. The text consists of 14 articles as follows: Explanations to the National Park (1); Purpose of protection (2); Regional development (3); Plan of National Park (4); Scientific documentation and research (5); Educational and public relations work (6); Recreation and route map (7); Prohibitions (8); Exceptions (9); Exemptions (10); National Park Office (11); National Park Advisory Board (12); Penalties (13).

Policy: Regional Law No. 393-ZAO “On subsistence farming”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law establishes economic and legal basis for subsistence farming, and measures for state support thereof. Subsistence farming shall be considered a form of non-commercial activity carried out by citizens and his family members (household) with a view of production and processing of agricultural commodities for individual personal needs. Maximum land area of agricultural land parcel that can be allotted to a household shall not exceed 10 percent of total available agricultural land area. Local self-government shall carry out mandatory registration of household carrying out subsistence farming. State support shall be carried out in the following forms: (a) annual veterinary inspection of farm animals free of charge; (b) assistance in trade of agricultural commodities; and (c) allotment of pastures and hayland.

Policy: Regulation on Environmental Impact Assessment.
Policy_Content: The Ministry of Environment and Forestry is authorized to decide when an “Environmental Impact Assessment" is positive,negative, required or not. The Ministry could hand over this authority to Governors. Any project subject to this Regulation shall neither start, nor any incentives be granted without a definite decision by the Ministry or by related Governor . Projects subject to this Regulation are listed in Annex-I and Annex-II. Annex-I provides list of projects where Environmental Impact Assessment is mandatory and Annex-II provides list of projects whose selection criteria must be applied. Environmental Impact Assessment shall be carried out as per projects in Annex-II if required by the reviewing committee. A committee shall be instituted, including representatives from related state institutions and agencies, from the Ministry of Environment and Forestry, and project leader or his/her representatives. When necessary representatives from universities, research agencies, vocational chambers, unions and other civil society organizations shall be invited to the committee. mmittee findings will be submitted to the Ministry for final decision. Project leaders shall be asked to modify the project for minor points to avoid complete rejection. Projects fully rejected after assessment could be reconsidered if conditions causing rejection change. Projects endorsed after Environmental Impact Assessment should commence within 5 years or the assessment shall be considered as null and void.

The use of the plots of subsoil containing deposits of generally used minerals or of the plots of land of local importance to be used for purposes not connected with the extraction of minerals must be carried out exclusively on the basis of the licence on the use of subsoil issued and registered by the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of the Republic of Tatarstan. The document consists of 14 Sections and contains 2 Annexes. Sec.1 lays down general provisions. Section 2 establishes the system of licensing. Section 3 classifies the users of subsoil. Sec.4 determines the plots of subsoil that can be conceded in use. Section 5 classifies the plots of land. Section 6 determines the types of licences and their contents. Section 7 establishes the system of the selection of candidates for obtaining licence. Section 8 determines the mechanism of concession of licence. Sec 9 determines the rights and the duties of the holders of licence. Section 10 gives the grounds for restriction, suspension or cancellation of the right of the use of subsoil. Section 11 determines the conditions for invalidation of licences. Section 12 regards control over the fulfilment of conditions of the use of subsoil. Section 13 regards payment for the use of subsoil. Section 14 establishes liability for the infringement of the legislation on subsoil. Annex 1 contains application form for obtaining licence for the use of subsoil. Annex 2 contains the list of documents that must be attached to the application form.
Subject: Mineral resources
Geographical_area: Arctic, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Black Sea, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, North Pacific, North-West Pacific
Entry into force notes: Entry into force from the date of issue.

Policy: Arrêté nº107/MMRE/DRGM du 15 décembre 2003, portant création du Programme de renforcement et de diversification du secteur minier au Niger (PRDSM).
Policy_Content: Il est créé sous la tutelle du ministre des mines et de l'énergie, maître d'oeuvre, un programme dénommé  « Programme de renforcement et de diversification du secteur minier au Niger 8 ACP NIR 54 ». Les objectifs généraux du programme sont: le maintien des performances économiques du pays par la sauvegarde de la filière uranium et la mise en valeur progressive de nouvelles ressources minérales; la réduction de la pauvreté au niveau local et l'atténuation des incidences sur l'environnement des exploitations artisana1es. L'objectif spécifique du programme est le renforcement des capacités de l'Etat à promouvoir le potentiel minier du Niger auprès des investisseurs privés nationaux et internationaux et à réguler le secteur.
Subject: Mineral resources

It changes its name to the State Secretariat for Agriculture, Supply, Aquaculture and Fisheries (SEAG), aimed at promoting the sustainable development of agriculture, fisheries, aquaculture and agribusiness in Espírito Santo. The Secretariat is responsible to perform the following activities: promote, coordinate, guide, stimulate and regulate agricultural, aquaculture and fishing activities; promote, coordinate and stimulate research programmes, studies, surveys and analysis of interest in these sectors; coordinate and monitor the elaboration of plans, programmes and projects for the development of the agricultural, agrarian, fishing and aquaculture sectors of the State; promote, coordinate and evaluate the execution of forest development policy and the preservation, conservation and recovery of renewable natural resources within the State; promote, coordinate and evaluate the execution of the control, inspection, plant health protection, as well as health protection of products of animal origin; elaborate, coordinate and evaluate land policy, the execution of the projects, integrated with the National Plan of Agrarian Reform; develop other actions aimed at promoting sustainable rural development in Espírito Santo.

Policy: Regional Decree No. 247 validating the Regulation on state reserve “Akatovsky”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Decree establishes that state zoological reserve “Akatovky” shall be constituted for unlimited time period without land expropriation from landowners. The main tasks of the reserve shall be as follows: (a) preservation, restoration and reproduction of valuable from economic, scientific and cultural point of view wild fauna species subject to hunting, rare and endangered species wild fauna species subject to hunting, preservation of their habitat, migratory routes, nesting sites; (b) performing biotechnical measures in order to create the most favorable living conditions for protected game; (c) systematic accounting and registration of wild fauna species subject to hunting; and (d) promotion and implementation of best practices for the protection and reproduction of wild fauna species subject to hunting. The following activities shall be prohibited on the territory of the reserve: (a) land development and plowing up; (b) keeping unleashed dogs, testing and training of dogs, use of dogs for grazing of cattle; (c) all types of hunting; (d) industrial procurement of mushrooms, berries and medicinal plants; (e) main use felling in protected forest areas and any type of felling within 200 m belt along river banks populated by beavers; (f) allotment of land plots for horticulture, gardening, smallholding and housing construction; (g) hydrotechnical amelioration, irrigation, geological exploration of subsoil and mining; (h) application of pesticides, plant protection chemicals, nutrients, growth stimulants, and open-air storage of fertilizers; (i) explosive works; (j) organization of rest areas, bivouacs, tourist stations, camps and other forms of collective recreation, pollution and littering of the reserve; (k) transit and parking of motor vehicles; and (l) any other type of economic activity, recreational activity and other categories of nature management that could have a negative impact on the territory of reserve.
Subject: Forestry, Wild species & ecosystems

Policy: Environmental Protection (Controls on Dangerous Substances) Regulations 2003 (S.I. No. 3274 of 2003).
Policy_Content: Regulation 3 sets out exclusions to the restrictions on the placing on the market and use of dangerous substances and preparations under the Regulations. Regulation 4 prohibits the placing on the market from 6th January 2004 of short chain chlorinated paraffins in concentrations greater than 1 percent for use in metalworking or for fat liquoring of leather. Regulation 5 prohibits the use of arsenic compounds as substances or constituents of preparations intended for specified uses. The placing on the market of wood treated with substances or preparations containing arsenic compounds is also prohibited. Regulation 6 contains derogations to the restrictions in regulation 5, such that inorganic compounds of the copper, chromium, arsenic (CCA) type C may be used as substances and preparations in the preservation of wood in industrial installations using vacuum or pressure to impregnate wood. Wood so treated may not be placed on the market before fixation of the preservative is completed. Wood treated with CCA solutions in industrial installations may be placed on the market for professional and industrial uses specified in regulation 6(3) and subject to conditions specified in regulations 6(6) and (7).
Subject: Forestry, Waste & hazardous substances

Policy: Ministerial Joint Decree No. 50388/2704/Ε103 amending and completing Cabinet Decree No. 2/1.2.2001 on fresh waters emission standards with regard to discharges of certain dangerous substances belonging to List II of Council Directive 76/464/EEC.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree aims at the implementation of the provisions of article 9 of Law 1650/1986 and at the same time aims at fully complying with the provisions of article 7 of Council Directive 76/464/EEC, so as to protect the aquatic environment of the country from pollution which is particularly caused by discharges to waters containing certain persistent, toxic and bioaccumulable substances which are included into List II of the aforementioned Directive. Thus, article 4 of Cabinet Decree No. 2/1.2.2001 referring to the national Programme on pollution reduction is hereby amended. Also, Annex II of article 6 to the aforementioned degree is replaced by the Annex to the present Ministerial Decree. The present Annex establishes the national Program for pollution reduction of surface waters for the compounds of List II, candidates for List I (C176, 14/07/1982/EEC), according to article 7 of Directive 76/464/EEC. Aim of the Programme is to control and reduce the substances found in the surface waters of the country and referred to in the Lists. The competent authority for the implementation of the Programme shall be the Department of Waters, Environmental Planning Directorate (under the Ministry of Environment, Spatial Planning and Public Works), supported by an inter-ministerial Steering Committee. With the Programme, a national network for monitoring of surface waters quality is created. The network comprises 183 monitoring and sampling stations established on 11 river bodies, 7 lakes and 4 marine areas (listed in the Programme). The choice of points of sampling and monitoring stations has been done in such a way so as to cover all water bodies of the country. Field of application of the Program are the internal surface waters and  internal coastal (brackish) waters of the national territory.

Policy: Rural Electrification Act.
Policy_Content: This Act establishes the Rural Electrification Authority as an independent body corporate with perpetual succession and a common seal, with the capacity to sue and be sued in its corporate name. The Authority performs a host of functions, including to administer and manage the Rural Electrification Fund; to develop, implement and update rural electrification master plans for the systematic electrification of rural areas; promote the utilization of available rural electrification technological options promote the utilization of available rural electrification technological options to enhance the contribution of energy to the development of agriculture, industry, mining and other economic activities in rural areas; mobilise funds from within and outside Zambia in support of rural electrification; to offer, on a competitive basis, the construction of rural electrification projects and periodically publish information on programmes being carried out; to design and offer, on a competitive basis, to developers or operators, smart subsidies for capital costs on projects that are designed to supply energy for development of rural areas; in conjunction with stakeholders, develop mechanisms for the operation of grid extension networks for rural electrification and other rural energy supply systems; to finance project preparation studies for rural electrification projects in accordance with guidelines developed and approved by the Authority; to recommend to Government policies for the enhancement of access to electricity by the rural populations; amongst others. The Act also provides for the composition of the Authority and details the tenure of office of members, as well as issues of vacancy of seat. The Act also constitutes a Secretariat of the Authority which functions to implement the decisions of the Authority. The Act further establishes the Rural Electrification Fund which consists of money set aside by the Parliament for the purposes of the fund, electricity levies collected and incidental money paid into the Fund by way of loans, grants or donations. The Act vests power on the Minister to make regulations for the administration of the Act.

Policy: Law No. 1378-IV on land valuation.
Policy_Content: The present Law establishes legal principles of carrying out land valuation, professional valuation activity in the sphere of land valuation, and is aimed at the regulation of relations connected with land valuation, ensuring carrying out land valuation for the purpose of protection of legal interests of the state and other legal entities in the sphere of land valuation, information coverage of land taxation and land market. Normative monetary valuation of land is used to determine the amount of land tax, state duty on exchange, inheritance (except for inheritance by heirs of the first and second priority by law) (both cases of inheritance by law and cases of inheritance by will) and the right of representation, as well as cases of inheritance of property, the value of which is taxed at zero rate) and donation of land in accordance with the law, rent for land of state and municipal property, loss of agricultural and forestry production, the value of land over 50 hectares for outdoor sports and recreation -health facilities, as well as in the development of indicators and mechanisms for economic incentives for the rational use and protection of land. Land valuation activities include: (a) regulatory and methodological support for land valuation; (b) scientific activities; (c) registration in the State Register of Certified Land Surveyors; (d) development of land valuation documentation and entry of land valuation data into the state land cadastre; (e) state examination of technical documentation on land valuation and review of reports on expert monetary valuation of land plots; (f) approval of technical documentation on land valuation in accordance with the law; (g) provision of land valuation consulting services; and (h) other activities in the field of land valuation in accordance with the law. The document consists of 6 Sections and contains 28 articles. Section 1 (arts. 1-11) lays down general provisions. Section 2 (arts. 12-19) establishes the principles of carrying out land valuation. Section 3 (arts. 20-24) regards documentation on land valuation and its validation. Section 4 (arts. 25-26) regards state regulation in the sphere of land valuation and autonomous organizations in the sphere of land valuation. Section 5 (arts. 27-28) establishes liability for the infringement of the legislation on land valuation and regards dispute settlement in the aforesaid sphere. Section 6 lays down final provisions.
Subject: Land & soil
Geographical_area: Black Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA

Policy: Estrategia Nacional de Biodiversidad y Plan de de Acción de País para la Implementación de la Estrategia Nacional de Biodiversidad 2004-2015.
Policy_Content: El presente documento consta de dos instrumentos: a) la Estrategia Nacional de Biodiversidad; b) el Plan de de Acción de País para la Implementación de la Estrategia Nacional de Biodiversidad. La Estrategia Nacional de Biodiversidad es un documento de alcance nacional que establece el marco estratégico para la preservación y conservación de la biodiversidad, promoviendo el desarrollo sustentable, a efectos de garantizar el acceso a los beneficios para el bienestar de las generaciones presentes y futuras. Se contemplan como objetivos específicos mantener y restaurar los hábitats y ecosistemas naturales, protegiendo los ecosistemas que hayan sido modificados en entornos productivos y urbanos. El documento está organizado entorno a las siguientes líneas estratégicas: 1) Conservación y Restauración de Ecosistemas; 2) Preservación de Especies y del Patrimonio Genético; 3) Promoción de Prácticas Productivas Sostenibles; 4) Desarrollo e Implementación de Mecanismos para la Gestión Integral de la Diversidad Biológica; 5) Fortalecimiento de la Coordinación Interinstitucional e Intersectorial para la Gestión Integral de la Diversidad Biológica; 6) Involucramiento Ciudadano para la Conservación y Uso Sostenible de la Diversidad Biológica. El Plan de Acción permite la operatividad de la Estrategia y detalla los principales resultados esperados de corto (2006) mediano (2010) y largo (2015) plazo asociados, además de establecer una propuesta de agenda de implementación de las líneas de acción para el período de aplicación (2005–2015).

Policy: Regional Law No. 278-OZ “On turnover of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates relations concerning ownership, tenancy and disposal of land parcels and land shares of agricultural land located on the regional territory. State bodies and local government must perform rational land-use planning of agricultural land and protection thereof with a view of: (a) ensuring the right of citizens to favourable environment; (b) ensuring sustainable land tenure; (c) improvement of soil fertility; and (d) ensuring sustainable economic development of the producers of agricultural commodities. Owners, tenants and leaseholders of agricultural land must use it with purposeful specific designated use thereof. Particularly valuable agricultural land areas such as agricultural land of scientific research organizations and agricultural land with cadastre estimates exceeding by 20 percent average cadastre values, shall be used exclusively for agricultural purposes. Minimum land area of consolidated agricultural land parcels shall be 5 ha. In case of sale of agricultural land parcel regional administration shall be granted preferential terms of purchase.

Policy: Decree No. 1061 of 2003 of the Council of Ministers concerning the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry.
Policy_Content: This Decree defines the functions and powers of the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry and specifies the institutions that are included in the administrative framework of the Ministry. The Ministry's duties include: agriculture, horticulture and rural development; forestry; fisheries, game and reindeer husbandry; medical supervision, enforcement and prevention of animal diseases and animal welfare; the practice of veterinary medicine; foodstuffs as regards animal food and medical treatment of animals; veterinary border control; plant health and inputs used in agriculture and horticulture; ownership issues regarding the State denominated forestry land with the exception of protected areas and wilderness areas, and public waters that are within its area of responsibility; surveying and use of geographic information; supply of water and disposal of wastewater, the regulation of water, control of flood damage, draining and irrigation of the land, dam safety and maintenance of the water buildings, the state's obligations as the holder of a permit under the Water Act (264/1961) and other uses and other management of water including associated matters relating to boundary waters; Sustainable and multipurpose use, care and protection of renewable natural resources; the functions of the competent authority for purposes of the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund and other  European Funds. Agencies, institutions, corporations and other entities within the sphere of competence of the Ministry include: the Research Centre for Agrifood; the Forest Agency, the Forest Research Game and Fisheries Research Institute, the Food Agency, the Research Institute for Veterinary and Food, the Control Center for Plant Production, the Geodetic Institute, the Land Survey Office, the Agriculture and Forestry Information Centre, the Rural Industries Complaints Board, the Veterinary Medicine Accident Board; the Boreal Plant Breeding Corporation, the   Horticultural Development Fund and the Agricultural Intervention Fund. The Decree also provides with respect to certain aspects of the administration of the  Ministry.

Policy: Traditional Leadership and Governance Framework Act, 2003 (No. 41 of 2003).
Policy_Content: This Act makes provision with respect to traditional communities and traditional leadership in South Africa. It sets out the procedure and criteria for the recognition of traditional communities and leaders. A traditional community must transform and adapt customary law and customs relevant to the application of this Act so as to comply with the relevant principles contained in the Bill of Rights in the Constitution, in particular by- (a) preventing unfair discrimination; 10 (b) promoting equality; and (c) seeking to progressively advance gender representation in the succession to traditional leadership positions. Once the Premier has recognised a traditional community, it must establish a traditional council in line with principles set out in provincial legislation. The traditional council  shall administer the affairs of the traditional community in accordance with customs and tradition and be involved, among other things, in community development. The national government and all provincial governments must promote partnerships between municipalities and traditional councils through legislative or other measures, and, through legislative or other measures, provide a role for traditional councils or traditional leaders in respect of, among other things, land administration, agriculture, health, welfare, the administration of justice, disaster management, and the management of natural resources.
Subject: General
Geographical_area: Africa, AFRICA FAO, South Atlantic, Southern Africa

Policy: Regional Law No. 63-OZ on maximum size of the plots of land conceded to citizens in ownership.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law establishes size (maximum and minimum) of the plots of land that can be conceded to citizens for the purpose of farming, gardening, truck farming, animal husbandry and suburban housing construction out of stock of state and municipal land. Maximum size of the plots of land: for farming – 200 ha; for animal husbandry – 5 ha for each conventional head of livestock; for gardening, truck farming and suburban housing construction – 0, 5 ha. Minimum size of the plots of land ; for farming except for cases envisaged by the federal legislation, - 1,9 ha ; for animal husbandry – 1 ha for each conventional head of livestock ; for gardening, truck farming and suburban housing construction – 0,04 ha.

Policy: Fisheries Law.
Policy_Content: The Law includes 10 Chapters: Chapter I, General provisions; Chapter II, Protection and development of fisheries resources; Chapter III, Fishing operations; Chapter IV, Aquaculture;Chapter V, Fishing vessels and service units for fisheries activities; Chapter VI, Processing, sales, import and export of fish and fishery products; Chapter VII, International cooperation on fisheries activities; Chapter VIII, State management of fisheries activities; Chapter IX, Rewards and sanctions; Chapter X, Executive provisions. The present Law deals with all issues related to both aquaculture and mariculture, the ecosystem preservation, the protection of fish and of the environment, the regulation for fishing vessel navigation, docking and transportatio. Moreover it disciplines the conduct of fishermen, the fishing gear and methods allowed or prohibited, the seasons and size of catch, the functions and responsibilities of the competent Authorities. Overall the law aims to improve the fishing activities while avoiding potential environmental damages and preserving the natural fishing resources.

Policy: Accord de coopération du 10 décembre 2003 entre l'Etat fédéral, la Communauté flamande, la Communauté française, la Communauté germanophone, la Commission communautaire commune, la Commission communautaire française, la Région wallonne et la Région de Bruxelles-Capitale, visant la collaboration dans les domaines de l'environnement et de la santé.
Policy_Content: Accord de coopération du 10 décembre 2003 entre l'Etat fédéral, la Communauté flamande, la Communauté française, la Communauté germanophone, la Commission communautaire commune, la Commission communautaire française, la Région wallonne et la Région de Bruxelles-Capitale, visant la collaboration dans les domaines de l'environnement et de la santé. Plus précisément le présent accord a pour objectif: 1. de veiller à la coordination de la rédaction, du suivi de la mise en oeuvre et de la révision du NEHAP (le plan national d'action environnement-santé reprenant les principales données fédérales, régionales et communautaires en ce qui concerne les relations entre l'environnement et la santé et les plans et actions menés par les autorités concernées); 2. de veiller, là où les compétences sont réparties entre les parties au présent accord, à une mise en oeuvre coordonnée du NEHAP dans la mesure où les actions et projets concernés correspondent aux critères d'intersectorialité, d'interterritorialité et de transdisciplinarité et requièrent un financement commun. La partie initiale contient la définition de certains termes comme, par exemple, «NEHAP», «Autorité fédérale ministres régionaux», «ministres communautaires», «CIMES» (La Conférence interministérielle (mixte) de l'Environnement élargie à la Santé), «Cellule: Le texte comprend 21 articles répartis en 5 chapitres comme suit: Définitions (Ier); Objectif(s) (II); Missions, structure et fonctionnement de la Conférence et de la Cellule Environnement-Santé (III); Dispositions budgétaires (IV); Dispositions finales (V).

Policy: Regional Law No. 893-OD on purposeful Cossack stock of land.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law, for the purpose of preservation and support of the traditional way of life of the Cossack associations, recorded in accordance with the established modalities in the state register of the Cossack societies of the Russian Federation, regulates the relations as regards the formation of the purposeful regional Cossack stock of land for the concession of the plots of land to the Cossack societies. Purposeful Cossack stock of land shall be formed for the purpose of allotment of the plots of land to the Cossack associations for agricultural purposes and for the fulfilment of the obligations thereof as regards state duty and other services (Article 2). The Regional Law consists of 5 Articles. Article 1 establishes the modalities of the formation of the purposeful stock of land. Article 2 determines the purposes of the formation of the purposeful stock of land. Article 3 regards the modalities of the allotment of the plots of land out of the purposeful stock of land. Article 4 deals with registration of the plots of land belonging to the purposeful stock of land. Article 5 determines the modalities of entry into force of the present Regional Law.

Policy: Law 3199 on water protection and management – Harmonization with EU Directive No. 2000/60/EC.
Policy_Content: A new legislative and institutional framework has been put into force in the country. It consists of Law 3199/03 on "water protection and the sustainable management of the water resources" with which the EU Water Framework Directive (No.2000/60/EC) is transposed into the national legislation. This new framework Law foresees a radical reorientation of the respective administrative capacities in Greece and introduces an innovative and holistic approach concerning water management that recognizes explicitly the ecological function of water. It also lays emphasis on management of water on river basins level as well as on the water pricing so that it reflects its full costs.

Policy: Law on Energy.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates the social relations associated with the activities of generation, import and export, transmission, transit transmission, distribution of electric and heat energy and natural gas, use of renewable energy resources, etc. as well as the authorities of state bodies in defining energy policy, regulation and control functions (art. 1). The main objectives of this Law shall be to create conditions for: (a) high-quality and secure supply of electricity, heat and natural gas to the general public; (b) energy development and the energy security of the country through efficient utilization of energy and energy resources; (c) sustainable development in the utilization of renewable energy sources, including generation of electricity from renewable energy sources in the interests of environmental protection; development of energy production infrastructures; protection of the life and health of citizens, property, the environment, and national interests (art. 2).The State Energy and Water Regulatory Commission, which is an independent state institution, shall regulate the energy sector (art. 10). Functions of the Commission shall include: (a) to issue, revise, amend, suspend, terminate and withdraw licences; (b) to decide on the classification of the electric power lines, heat energy pipelines, natural gas pipelines; (c) to issues certificates to electricity producers utilizing renewable energy resources (art. 21). Activities subject to licensing under this Law are: (a) generation of electricity and/or heat energy; (b) transmission of electricity, heat and natural gas; (c) distribution of electricity or natural gas; (d) storage of natural gas; (e) trade in electricity; (f) public supply of electricity or natural gas; (g) transit transmission of natural gas; (h) management of the elevtricity system; etc. (art. 39).

Policy: Law No. 51 “On apiculture”.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates relations in the sphere of apiculture, protection, management and reproduction of bee families, raising the efficiency of apiculture, and also protection of legal rights and interests of natural and legal persons carrying out apiculture. The Act consists of 5 Sections divided into 21 articles: (1) general provisions; (2) apiculture; (3) protection of bees; (4) state regulation in the sphere of apiculture; and (5) conclusive provisions. Natural and legal persons shall be granted the right to carry out apiculture without licence and to set up social associations on apiculture. Persons, cultivating entomophilous plants, can use bee families owned by other natural and legal persons for pollinating the aforesaid plant, with a view of raising productivity thereof, in accordance with contracts. Protection and reproduction of bees shall be ensured by: (a) protection of natural habitats of bees; (b) veterinary and sanitary servicing of apiaries; (c) arrangements for the prevention of wilful destruction of bee families; and (d) protection of bee families in the process of application of fertilizers and other agrochemicals.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development

Policy: Regional Law No. 277-OZ on forestry, use, protection and reproduction of municipal forest on the regional territory.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law regulates legal relations in the field of forest management, use, protection and reproduction of municipal forest on the regional territory. The Regional Law consists of 12 Articles. Article 1 regards legislation on municipal forest. Article 2 regards municipal forest. Article 3 regards management of municipal forest. Article 4 determines the main requirements as regards the use of municipal forest. Article 5 regards the use of the territory (part of the territory) of urban settlements covered by municipal forest for construction and expansion of works. Article 6 classifies the types of forest management in municipal forest. Article 7 determines the modalities of stay of citizens in municipal forest. Article 8 regards reproduction of municipal forest and forest-growing. Article 9 regards conservation and protection of municipal forest. Article 10 regards financing of arrangements in the field of forest management, utilization, conservation, protection and reproduction of municipal forest. Article 11 establishes liability for the infringement of the present Regional Law. Article 12 determines the modalities of entry into force of the present Regional Law.

Policy: Petroleum Market Law (No. 5015).
Policy_Content: The objective of this Law is to regulate the guidance, surveillance and supervision for the purpose of ensuring the transparent, non-discriminatory and stable delivery of petroleum supplied from domestic and foreign resources to consumers, directly or after processing, in a reliable, cost-effective manner within a competitive environment. The Law consists of three Parts divided into 28 articles dealing with the following matters: general provisions (Part I, arts. 1 - 23); amendments to the Electricity Market Law (Part II, arts. 24-28); temporary provisions (Part III). Holding a license is obligatory for the following petroleum activities: (a) performing refining, processing, lube oil production, storage, transmission; (b) performing liquid fuel distribution, transportation and vendor activities. The process of granting, updating and temporarily suspending or cancelling the licenses shall be undertaken by the Authority. In granting licenses, the technology, quality, safety and sustainability of the enterprise and service . The licensees must undertake the necessary arrangements to prevent environmental risks and to compensate any loss of damage caused to environment as a result of their operations.

Policy: Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003 (16 U.S.C. 6501 et seq.)
Policy_Content: This act concerns forest restoration. Its purposes are to reduce wildfire risk to communities, municipal water supplies, and other at-risk Federal land through a collaborative process of planning, prioritizing, and implementing hazardous fuel reduction projects; to authorize grant programs to improve the commercial value of forest biomass (that otherwise contributes to the risk of catastrophic fire or insect or disease infestation) for producing electric energy, useful heat, transportation fuel, and petroleum-based product substitutes, and for other commercial purposes; to enhance efforts to protect watersheds and address threats to forest and rangeland health, including catastrophic wildfire, across the landscape; to promote systematic gathering of information to address the impact of insect and disease infestations and other damaging agents on forest and rangeland health; to improve the capacity to detect insect and disease infestations at an early stage, particularly with respect to hardwood forests; and to protect, restore, and enhance forest ecosystem components — to promote the recovery of threatened and endangered species; to improve biological diversity; and to enhance productivity and carbon sequestration.

Policy: Law on civil protection.
Policy_Content: The present Law determines the main targets, organizational principles of the structuring and functioning of civil protection, the competence of the executive bodies, enterprises, institutions and organizations, the rights and the duties of the nationals, foreign and stateless natural persons in the sphere of civil protection. The main tasks of civil protection service: 1) organization, development and maintenance of early warning system of the population; 2) observation and laboratory control over radiation, chemical, bacteriological and biological situation;  3) protection of foodstuffs, water supply systems, alimentary raw materials, fodder, animals and plants against radioactive, chemical, bacteriological and biological contamination, and also epizooties and epiphytes (art. 3). The arrangements of civil protection service in the sphere of the protection of the population, territories and objects against natural and technological disasters include: 1) land use planning with the consideration of the possible flooding, mudflows, landslide and other dangerous exogenous natural phenomena; 2) organization of the system of monitoring, notification of the population and economic entities of man-caused accidents, possible flooding, mudflows, landslide and other dangerous exogenous natural phenomena (art. 5). The Law consists of 8 Sections composed of 32 articles.
